item.title: Hong Kong | Main opposition party dissolved
item.description: The Hong Kong Democratic Party yesterday approved its own dissolution, under pressure from the territory's security laws, which prevent it from carrying out its activities. In a two-hour meeting, 97 percent of members voted to disband the party, once one of the biggest forces in Hong Kong's Legislative Council. At the annual assembly, according to the South China Morning Post, a total of 117 members, 97 percent of those present, agreed to the party's dissolution, following the decision taken by the party leadership in February. Veteran member and former deputy Fred Li Wah-ming said a mainland Chinese official had urged the party to dissolve before December's Legislative Council elections. This dissolution of the party eliminates what little remains of the city's main political opposition, following a similar decision by the League of Social Democrats in June and the closure of the Civic Party in 2023. The Hong Kong Association for Democracy and People's Welfare, which focuses on social issues and advocates for residents to vote under the revamped electoral system, is the only remaining pro-democracy force. The patriots Currently, with the various arrests of leaders and activists and the limitations on candidacies, the democratic party did not have any representation in the legislative council or district councils. The issue became even more complex in March 2021, when the Chinese government passed a law designed to ensure that only those it designated as 'patriots' could govern in Hong Kong. This regulation significantly reduced democratic representation in the assembly, consolidated control over electoral processes and established a candidate selection panel aligned with Beijing's interests. Since this legislation and electoral reforms came into force, the future of the Democratic Party has been at risk, following constant police raids and arrests of activists or family members in recent years. A few months ago, party members authorized the sale of their headquarters for 11 million Hong Kong dollars to prepare for eventual dissolution and prevent the property from being handed over to the courts. The party's remaining funds are to be donated to the Association for the Rights of Victims of Industrial Accidents.

item.title: Light Rail | Public consultation on route in 2026
item.description: The Government plans to move forward with a public consultation on Light Rail planning in the first half of 2026. The information was provided by the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam, on the sidelines of the Charity March. According to Radio Macau's Chinese language channel, the secretary indicated that the consultation will be carried out after the data on the different routes that are being analyzed in a strategic study that is underway has been completed. The plans under study include a Southern Line, which will connect the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge border post to Barra station, passing through Zone A of New Landfills, NAPE, Nam Van and Sai Van. A West Line is also planned, from the port of Qingmao to Barra, and a North Line from Taipa, to connect Zone A of the New Landfills to the Oceano station via landfill zones E, D and C. The plans also include a connection from Seac Pai Van to the entrance to the urban area of ​​Coloane.

item.title: Universities of Macau and Timor-Leste agree to exchange students and teachers
item.description: The Macau Polytechnic University (UPM) announced on Friday an agreement with the National University of Timor-Leste (UNTL) for the exchange of students and teachers. In a statement, UPM indicated that the cooperation protocol also provides for the strengthening of ties in the area of ​​sharing academic resources and the training of qualified staff bilingual in Chinese and Portuguese. Both jurisdictions have Portuguese as one of their official languages, along with Chinese, in the case of the semi-autonomous region of Macau, and with Tetum, in the case of East Timor. The agreement was signed by the vice-rector of UPM, Vivian Lei Ngan Lin, and the rector of UNTL, João Soares Martins, on the sidelines of the 15th conference of the Forum for Higher Education Management in Portuguese-Speaking Countries and Regions (Forges). The annual meeting of Portuguese-speaking universities and polytechnics took place in the capital of Timor-Leste, Díli, in a joint organization of UNTL, the Timorese Catholic University São João Paulo II and the University of Díli. The Forges conference, which had as its theme “The Promotion of Scientific Research in the Portuguese Language in the Face of Global Challenges”, took place between the 24th and 27th of November. During the event, the deputy director of the Faculty of Languages ​​and Translation at UPM, the Portuguese Joaquim Carvalho, gave a presentation in which he invited students and teachers from Portuguese-speaking countries to invest in exchanges with Macau. International Network The UPM delegation also took advantage of the opportunity to discuss academic exchange and cooperation projects with the Portuguese Catholic University, the Pontifical Catholic University of Campinas (Brazil) and the University of Luanda. In November 2024, during the 14th Forges conference, in Macau, João Soares Martins told Lusa that UNTL wanted the support of the Instituto Português do Oriente (IPOR) to start certifying proficiency in the Portuguese language. Also in the Chinese region, UNTL and the University of Macau (UM) signed a cooperation agreement on Monday that provides “more opportunities for the mobility of teachers and students”, highlighted the rector. The Timorese delegation visited the Department of Portuguese at UM, the State Reference Laboratory for Quality Research in Chinese Medicine and the Faculty of Law, where some of the current UNTL teachers were trained. “It would be good for the University of Macau to be able to provide some vacancies for our teachers to continue their courses, both in master's and doctorate degrees”, highlighted Soares Martins.

item.title: China Arts Fund | Selected Macau projects
item.description: The list of candidates selected for financial support from the China National Arts Fund (General Projects) for the year 2026 will include 13 projects submitted by artistic institutions, higher education institutions, companies and artists in the Macao SAR, the Office of the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture announced on Saturday. This is the fifth time that Macau's artistic and cultural projects have been selected for the national financing plan. The central authorities began to allow applications from Hong Kong's special administrative regions from 2021. In a statement, the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, thanked the motherland for the recognition and support given to the development of Macau's arts and culture and warmly congratulated Macau's authors. The selected projects include dance performances, Chinese opera, paintings celebrating nationalism, a musical and creative talent training programs from the Hou Kong Dance Association, Macau University of Science and Technology and City University of Macau. In 2022, nine Macao SAR projects were selected for the first time and the following year 11 applications were distinguished. For the years 2024 and 2025, 10 projects were financed per year, while next year the support will cover the largest number of projects.

item.title: ONE | Construction of the new campus has started
item.description: The construction start ceremony was attended by Sam Hou Fai. The new campus will include UM's first medical school Construction of the new campus of the University of Macau (UM), which will include the first public medical faculty, in collaboration with the University of Lisbon (ULisboa) began on Friday. In a statement, UM indicated that the laying of the first stone ceremony, presided over by Government leader, Sam Hou Fai, took place in the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone, in neighboring Hengqin (Mountain Island). The new campus will occupy an area of ​​almost 376,000 square meters in the special economic zone and construction is expected to take around three years, with a partial inauguration scheduled for 2028 and completion of works in 2029. Four new faculties will be created in the new UM campus on Ilha da Montanha, including those of Information Sciences, Design and Engineering, as well as the first public medical faculty in Macau. The University of Science and Technology of Macau, a private institution, has had a Faculty of Health Sciences since 2008, officially renamed the Faculty of Medicine in 2019. In June, the director of the Faculty of Medicine at Ulisboa told Lusa that doctors trained at the future Faculty of Medicine at UM will also be able to practice in Portugal. ULisboa is collaborating with UM to create a curriculum with a layout “close to the structure” of courses at the Portuguese institution, said Luís Graça. The director explained that the courses will work in co-supervision, allowing doctors trained at UM to obtain “equivalence and recognition” by the ULisboa Faculty of Medicine. Doctors for Portugal Among the advantages will be “thus allowing doctors trained in the territory to also practice medicine in Portugal”, highlighted the researcher. In December, the vice-rector of UM, Rui Martins, said that the new campus will focus on "'dual degrees' [courses in co-tutelship] with foreign universities. Medicine is already with Lisbon and now we are defining it for the other faculties". The new campus on Ilha da Montanha should allow UM to increase from the current 15 thousand to a maximum of 25 thousand students, highlighted the vice-rector for Global Affairs, in an interview with the Portuguese-language channel of the local public television TDM. Luís Graça, a specialist in transplant immunology, also expressed enthusiasm about potential collaborations between the two universities in the area of ​​scientific research. “If we think in terms of science, strengthening the scientific potential of both institutions with close collaboration between them is something that will clearly benefit both sides of this partnership”, stated the director. Luís Graça said that the ULisboa Faculty of Medicine is organizing the first symposium to bring together researchers from the institution and UM, with a view to promoting joint research projects.

item.title: Justice | Jerónimo Santos at TSI and Ho Wai Neng confirmed at TUI
item.description: Despite the departure of Portuguese people from Macau's courts in recent years, the only Portuguese judge remaining in the territory was promoted to the Court of Second Instance The only Portuguese judge working in Macau, Jerónimo Alberto Gonçalves Santos, was appointed to the Court of Second Instance (TSI), while Ho Wai Neng was confirmed as judge of the Court of Final Instance (TUI). The decisions were communicated on Friday and the appointment order was published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. The promotion of Jerónimo Santos comes at a time when the continuity of Portuguese magistrates in Macau is being called into question by the Portuguese authorities. In October of this year, fellow Portuguese judge Rui Ribeiro brought forward the end of a service commission, which lasted until May of next year, due to the uncertainty regarding the renewal of the special license, to be in Macau, from the Superior Council of Judiciary (CSM). Also in October, the president of the Supreme Court of Justice (STJ), João Cura Mariano, who inherently also presides over the CSM, stated that the Portuguese justice system is having “some difficulty in contributing judges”, due to the lack of qualified and experienced human resources. “Just now we removed a judge who had been here for many years and we needed him”, highlighted João Cura Mariano, in October. In 2024, the CSM rejected the stay of Portuguese TJB judge Carlos Carvalho, who had been in Macau for 16 years and had been invited by the Independent Commission for the Nomination of Judges in the territory to continue for another two years. The council did not authorize the renewal of Carlos Carvalho's special license and promoted him to judge, with placement at the Court of Appeal. Despite the nuances, João Cura Mariano assured that he was willing to help Macau, “despite the difficulties that currently exist in Portugal in recruiting judges”. Ascent confirmation The moves announced on Friday confirm Ho Wai Neng's elevation to the Court of Final Appeal, where he had been serving since Sam Hou Fai announced his candidacy for Chief Executive in April last year. Furthermore, Choi Mou Pan was appointed for a period of three years as president of the TSI, a position previously held by Ho Wai Neng. Among the promotions to the TSI, the name of Lou Ieng Ha also stands out, the judge responsible in the first instance for some of the most publicized cases in recent years, such as the Public Works case, which resulted in the convictions of former directors Jaime Carion and Li Canfeng, and also the Suncity case, which led to the businessman of Macau's largest gambling promoter, Alvin Chao, in prison. In terms of appointments, Io Weng San and Rong Qi were promoted to presiding judges of the Collective Court of First Instance Courts. All appointments take effect next year, and nominations came from the Independent Commission for the Nomination of Judges. The committee is made up of Lau Cheok Va, president, Ho Teng Iat, Ieong Tou Hong, Chan Hong, Wang Yu, Song Man Lei and António José Dias Azedo. With Lusa

item.title: Budget | Public expenditure rises until November due to social support
item.description: Compared to last year, the Government spent 4.1 percent more on social expenses until November, which rose to 49.7 billion patacas. The increase in public spending was balanced with casino revenues Public expenditure increased by 2.7 percent in the first 11 months of 2025, compared to the same period last year, following a budget review to reinforce social support, it was announced on Friday. According to data published online by the Financial Services Directorate (DSF), the Macao SAR spent 86.1 billion patacas by the end of November. The main reason for the increase was spending on social support and subsidies, which grew 4.1 percent compared to the first 11 months of 2024, to 49.7 billion patacas. At the beginning of July, the Legislative Assembly approved a Government proposal to increase the expenses foreseen in the budget by 2.86 billion patacas, to reinforce social support. The review includes the creation of a subsidy, worth a total of MOP54,000, for children up to three years old, in an attempt to increase the lowest birth rate in the world. On the contrary, spending on public works, the Administration's Investment and Expense Plan, fell 2.7 percent until November, to 14.7 billion patacas. Tax revenue The increase in expenditure was balanced by Macau's current revenue, which rose 2.8 percent in the first 11 months of the year, to 104.6 billion patacas. The main reason for the increase was a 7 percent increase, to 86.7 billion patacas, in revenue from gambling taxes – which represent 81.3 percent of the total. The city's six gaming operators pay a direct tax of 35 percent on gaming revenue, with 2.4 percent going to the Macau Social Security Fund and urban and tourism development, and 1.6 percent given to the Macau Foundation for cultural, educational, scientific, academic and philanthropic purposes. Total revenue from Macau's casinos reached 226.5 billion patacas in the first 11 months of the year, 8.6 percent more than in the same period in 2024. The territory ended November with a surplus in public accounts of 20.6 billion patacas, 11.4 percent more than in the same period last year. Macau closed 2024 with a surplus of 15.8 billion patacas, more than double that recorded in the previous year. The Government's initial forecast for the entire year 2025 pointed to a surplus of 6.83 billion patacas. But the revised budget, approved by the Legislative Assembly at the beginning of July, predicted a surplus of just 191.1 million patacas.

item.title: Japan | Interference in the cancellation of events denied
item.description: The Government denied any interference in the cancellation of at least three concerts with Japanese artists scheduled for Macau and guaranteed that these were solely commercial decisions by the organizers "I think that different parties have their own consideration factors", said, at a press conference, the president of the Cultural Heritage Council, Deland Leong Wai Man. "It is normal to have adjustments regarding concerts or different events. Situations of cancellation due to force majeure, is something common", added on Friday, also the leader of the Cultural Institute. On Tuesday, the Venetian Macau hotel-casino announced the cancellation of a concert by Japanese pop singer Ayumi Hamasaki, on January 10th. This is after Hamasaki's concert in Shanghai on November 29th was cancelled. On Wednesday, a Christmas show, scheduled for December 25th, at another hotel-casino, Studio City, which included the female band Say My Name, which includes the Japanese Hitomi Honda, the group's leader, and Terada Mei, was also cancelled. On the same day, a third show was cancelled, this time by the band Hi-Fi Un!corn, a group that includes Japanese artists, and which was scheduled for December 21st, at a third hotel-casino, Galaxy Macau. Asked by Lusa whether there were instructions from the Government not to hold cultural events with artists from Japan, Leong Wai Man assured that “this is a matter for the commercial sector, it is the organizer's decision”. “I have nothing more to add”, stressed the leader. Even so, Leong defended that the wave of cancellations “will not have a major impact” on the Executive's plan to position Macau as an international city of shows. Several fronts On November 15, Macau asked residents and tourists of the territory in Japan to raise their state of alert, after Beijing advised against traveling to the country following statements by the Japanese leader about Taiwan. The warning from the Tourism Services Bureau came “given that since the middle of this year, the trend of attacks in Japan against Chinese citizens has been increasing”, without citing data or examples. However, the Hong Kong Government did so, citing just one incident in Tokyo, in which two Chinese citizens were attacked by locals in late July. China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a warning advising against travel to Japan due to the deteriorating security environment. The main airlines in Mainland China, Macau and Hong Kong announced full refunds for flights to Japan, following the Government's appeal. The measure was taken at a time when tensions between Beijing and Tokyo worsened again, following statements by Japanese Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi.

item.title: Crime | Government does not release data on suicides and attempts
item.description:
After the Health Services, the Security department also stopped publishing data on suicides and attempts, after ten years of publication. The absence was noted in the release of crime data for the months of January to September this year, which show the increase in sexual abuse of minors to almost double
The Government stopped publishing data on suicide cases in Macau, as well as attempts. The absence of these numbers was noted by the newspaper Cheng Pou when it released crime data for the months of January and September this year on Friday. The publication even questions whether “the data on suicide has become ‘the secret that cannot be said’ of the authorities, committed to building a happy Macau”, remembering that this data began to be released in 2015. Highlight is the fact that the Health Services also stopped publishing the statistics, something that was done every three months. In the case of the Security Secretariat, the data was monthly and was broken down by sex, age group and methods used. The lack of numbers comes after Macau broke records in terms of suicide cases in 2024, registering 90 deaths, 2.27 percent more than in 2023. Compared to 2022, the increase was 12.5 percent. Of the 90 cases, 48 ​​concerned male victims and 42 female victims, aged between 12 and 76 years. The most recent data, for the first half of this year, reveals 41 deaths by suicide and 101 attempts. In the release of crime statistics, on Friday, only one case of death by suicide appears in relation to an episode of homicide between brothers, which occurred in August this year, in the north zone. Here, the older brother jumped from the balcony, being suspected of having killed his younger brother due to financial disputes. Break in crime Looking at the crime panorama in general terms, there is a drop of 7.1 percent in the months under analysis, compared to the same period last year. The territory's authorities highlighted the sharp drop in computer crimes. The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, said that the drop is due to the “decreasing trend” of “crimes that attract more attention from society”, including serious violent crime, theft, robbery, fraud and computer crimes. In the first nine months of the year, 187 violent crimes were recorded, which represents a drop of 11 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (210). Thefts, robberies and frauds fell by 7.7, 5.9 and 23.6 percent, respectively. Computer crime, which recorded 770 cases in the first nine months of 2024, showed a decline of 52.1 percent in the period under analysis, with 369 cases. The decline in cases of fraud using telecommunications, cyber fraud and computer fraud, said Chan Tsz King, “reflects the effectiveness of the prevention and combat work carried out by the police, and the significant increase in public awareness about fraud prevention”, he said. The Government also highlighted that crime related to illicit gambling increased by 985 percent between January and September this year, with 394 more cases compared to the same period in 2024. The increase is due to the entry into force, in October last year, of the law to combat illicit gambling crimes, which introduced “the new crime of ‘exploitation of illicit exchange for gambling’ and expanded the scope of coverage of some crimes related to illicit gambling”. For the same reason, said the secretary, gambling-related crimes soared in the first three quarters of 2025 – 1,737 cases, 70.1 percent more than in the same period last year. In the past, the official said, fraud committed by people illegally exchanging money outside casinos “could not be identified as related to gambling”. “However, with the criminalization of ‘illegal money exchange’ and the improvement of legal provisions”, these cases “are now included in gambling crime statistics, thus increasing the number of crimes”, he indicated. More abuse of minors Chan Tsz King, who took office in October and presented the crime report for the first time on Friday, also referred to a 6.1 percent increase in crimes against the person, with child sexual abuse increasing by 86.7 percent, from 15 cases in the first nine months of 2024 to 28 cases in the same period this year. The secretary explained that these are essentially “voluntary sexual acts between people of the same age”, with “transmission of photographs and pornographic images”, without forgetting cases of “less serious sexual harassment”. “Cases involving people with family relationships were also identified, which deserves the attention of society”, said Chan Tsz King, who released data on awareness-raising actions on this problem: more than 70 activities carried out by the police, which saw the participation of more than 12,000 people, including students, guardians and teaching staff. Drug trafficking and sale and drug consumption, in turn, registered an increase of 37.1 percent, with 13 more cases, and 72.7 percent, eight more cases, respectively. According to the secretary's presentation, the 48 cases registered in the three quarters and the respective increase are due to “the discovery of several cases of cross-border drug trafficking through the reinforcement of internal and external police cooperation”, highlighting a case that occurred in September, when 31 kilos of cannabis flower worth 31.77 million patacas were seized. Chan Tsz King said that this was “the biggest case of cannabis smuggling seized in the history of Macau”. Between walls In the case of the crime of rape, there was a decline in the number of rape crimes, to a total of 24 cases, 40 percent less than in the same period of the previous year. The Secretary for Security added that “more than 70 percent of the victims were not residents of Macau”, and “the majority of these crimes occurred in hotel rooms”, while “a number of these involved pecuniary conflicts between the victims and the suspects, and it is not possible to rule out the hypothesis that some of the cases occurred in the context of a sexual transaction”. In this context, the secretary clarified that the police authorities have been “in close communication with the hotel sector”, and “police devices and inspections in peripheral areas of hotels and casinos” have been reinforced. Between January and September, more than 160 police actions were carried out to combat prostitution, with 192 people suspected of engaging in prostitution activity being intercepted. Além disso, no período em causa foram resolvidos 17 casos da prática dos crimes de lenocínio ou de exploração de prostituição, com a detenção de 26 suspeitos. Silence as always Questioned by Lusa during the press conference about the first case to be investigated in Macau within the scope of national security, the secretary made no comments. “The case (…) is being handled by judicial entities and, due to secrecy, it would not be appropriate for the Secretary of Security to comment”, added Chan Tsz King, who was a Public Prosecutor when former deputy Au Kam San was detained. At the end of July, the territory's police announced the arrest of Au Kam San, the first under the state security defense law, which came into force in 2009, with the scope being expanded 14 years later. The accusation is not yet known and there is no information about who will defend the former deputy. With Lusa

item.title: CCM | “Operação Oops! – Um Musical” com bilhetes à venda
item.description: Tickets for a new show taking the stage at the Macau Cultural Center (CCM) have been on sale since yesterday. This is “Operation Oops! A Musical”, selected within the scope of the “Commissioning of Performing Arts Productions 2024-2026” program, and is a comedy that will be presented in three shows, from January 31st to February 2nd. Adapted from the novel of the same name by local playwright Lawrence Lei I Leong, this new production brings together artists from the region to bring to life a score composed by Golden Horse winner Leon Ko. The cast is led by Jordan Cheng, a multi-award winning performer from Macau, honored as Best Actor at the 31st Hong Kong Theater Awards, and the show is directed by Fong Chun Kit, one of the creative minds of the Hong Kong Repertory Theatre. The choreography is designed by local dance creator Florence Cheong, highlights a note from the Cultural Institute. “Operation Oops!” tells the award-winning story of a group of misfits who, disappointed by exorbitant rent prices, come up with a desperate and absurd plan. Thwarted by a series of unfortunate but amusing mishaps, the zero-budget mission goes headlong into a chaotic spiral.

item.title: Fighting between Thailand and Cambodia continues
item.description: Thailand and Cambodia continue fighting along the border, as the conflict enters its second week, after Bangkok denied that it had said “yes” to a ceasefire, announced by the President of the United States, Donald Trump. The hostilities, which broke out on December 7, have so far caused at least 33 deaths and more than 200 injuries, in addition to around 800,000 people being displaced on both sides of the border. The two countries accuse each other of having unleashed hostilities and attacking civilians. Last Friday, Donald Trump stated that the leaders of the two countries had agreed to a ceasefire after a phone call from him, but the Thai Government denied this commitment and the fighting continued this Saturday and continued yesterday. According to Thai Defense Ministry spokesman Surasant Kongsiri, Cambodia shelled several border provinces on Saturday night and yesterday. The Cambodian counterpart, Maly Socheata, accused Thai forces of continuing to bomb and fire mortars in areas close to the border since midnight on Sunday. Cambodia closed its land borders with Thailand this Saturday, leaving thousands of people stranded on both sides of the border. The decision, according to Phnom Penh, aims to protect civilians — including foreigners of various nationalities, who were unable to cross the border into Thailand — from the risks associated with military clashes, which last week included the use of fighter jets and artillery fire along the border, which is around 820 kilometers long. Cambodia has asked its citizens living in Thailand and Thais hoping to return to their country to remain where they are “until the ceasefire is fully enforced.” Thailand, in turn, expressed concern about this decision by Phnom Penh, especially as it expected the return on Saturday of around 7,000 Thais who had been waiting for days at the border to enter the country and who are now prohibited from crossing it by land. "These actions violate numerous provisions of international law that, for our part, Thailand respects. I guarantee that Cambodians and other foreign citizens living in Thailand will receive assistance in accordance with international law", said deputy spokesperson for the Thai Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Maratee Nalita Andamo, at a press conference yesterday. An old case Thailand and Cambodia dispute the sovereignty of territories where Khmer Empire temples are located along a border of around 820 kilometers, drawn at the beginning of the 20th century during the French colonial period. In July this year, a first episode of violence caused 43 deaths in five days and forced around 300,000 people to leave their homes in areas close to the common border, before a ceasefire under the auspices of the United States, China and Malaysia. The two countries then signed a ceasefire agreement on October 26, under the aegis of Donald Trump, which Bangkok suspended a few weeks later, following the explosion of a mine that injured several of its soldiers, and which Thailand accuses of having been installed after the ceasefire.

item.title: Takeaway | No labor regulation plans
item.description: Chan Un Tong, director of the Department of Labor Affairs (DSAL), said there are no plans on the table to regulate the courier profession, which is intended to deliver take-away meals. According to TDM Rádio Macau, the person in charge responded to a written question from deputy Ngan Iek Hang, explaining that the labor and legal protection of couriers depends on the link they have with the platform that provides the delivery service. If there is a signed contract, the current labor law applies, but if there is only a service provision contract, the conditions agreed between the parties apply. The deputy stated, in the interpellation, that the take-away delivery sector already represents 48.3 percent of catering establishments, therefore suggesting improvements at a labor level.

item.title: Carlos Morais José
item.description: Our approach to reality, no matter how disciplined and honest the approach to thought, is always ridden by error, especially when there is no alternative to the use of imagination. Geniuses, the ancient Greeks knew about the Earth's sphericity and that's why they attributed a maximum circle to the planet, which they named Ison. Today we call it Ecuador. However, these Hellene geographers considered these regions to be unreachable and uninhabitable. Torrid Zone: there, unbearable heat would boil the oceans, preventing the passage to temperate zones, postulated further south of this line that marked the maximum circle of the sphere. A simple islet, named “das Rolas”, a mere hundred meters from the island of São Tomé, in the Gulf of Guinea, is crossed by this equatorial line. This location of the former Portuguese colony provides it with a type of climate that is only found with such intensity close to the equator: the temperature varies little and, contrary to what the Greeks thought, it does not reach excessive values. Its range is between 20 and 29 degrees Celsius, but the “normal” temperature remains between 23 and 25 degrees. Night, day and throughout the year. In the permanently cloudy sky, the Sun and Moon are rarely seen. And when this happens, they never fail to appear wrapped in veils of clouds, which gives them an unreal character, invoking ancient magic, witnessing moving skies. When, towards the end of the afternoon, the rain extends its reign for more than two or three hours, often presented to plants and animals by a thunderstorm, the light dies and a very dark night reigns over the land and sea. The stars fall beyond the clouds that cover everything. On a night like this, there is no moonlight to illuminate or pierce the clouds. A deep pitch falls on the earth, a darkness that is impenetrable to our eyes. And it was like that, at three in the morning, that I woke up. My eyes opened to an abysmal darkness. Nothing, absolutely nothing could be seen. He knew he had the window open, but not a ray of light deigned to enter the room. I reached out, but the lamp didn't work. The electricity was out again. I waited for some time, hoping to get used to the blackness and discover some shapes in it. In vain. He was immersed in a well of black, warm water, he could feel the humidity on his skin, which had just woken up sweaty from a nightmare. I decided to get up and leave the house, looking for some light. The rain had stopped. Outside, the forest celebrated, hummed, reverberated with sounds. There would be millions of insects, amphibians, vertebrates, all of them nocturnal animals, also immersed in the dark, where they found food, sex and salvation. Life didn't need light. It was heard, deafening. At the edge of that spontaneous excess of trees and plants, nothing could be seen either. Dark, impenetrable dark. Only the sound prevailed, louder and louder, and suggested movements among the trees. That mixture of buzzing, squealing, buzzing, ringing, rales, loudly surrounded my ears, building a helmet that blocked all other senses, including the one that affects me in space. I was dizzy. And in that half-daziness, I groped my way back to the house, to my bed. There was nothing he could do. Forget the coffee, eliminate the possibility of reading or consulting a computer. Lying in the dark as if waking up in a coffin. Our mind cannot handle fear for long. Mostly irrational. As was the case. I can't really talk about fear, fear, but about discomfort, derived from the fragile situation that I attributed to myself. Everything could happen in that dark, and I wouldn't see him. If for some reason you had to leave the room, where would you go, if everything was plunged into darkness? But nothing was happening in the darkness of my room, nor would anything happen that would force me to grope through the pitch black, looking for a light. On the contrary, in that bed I was protected by the dark and if I saw nothing nothing would see me either. This thought provided some comfort. All things considered, that abysmal pitch was strangely comfortable for me. I made it a protective cloak and not a space of threats. And so I remained. The ancient Chinese say that everyone has an excellent place to stay. A place where you can develop and enjoy who you really are. Maybe this dark package is mine. Perhaps in it I can be for myself what I really am, setting aside what surrounds me, instructs and distracts me. I am undoubtedly alone. Without the possibility of communicating with another person or even acting in my surroundings. I'm left. With me. Alone. Isolated. Here I am not the anthropologist, nor the editor, none of my social titles perform any functions. I am not the husband, the friend or the lover. From the outside I only have the language that inhabits me and my brain rebels in search of meaning. And even this takes second place in daydreams whose material seems to emerge from another place, from knowledge not conditioned to a language — an impression of the world and not its explanation. I am a consciousness separated from things, which in the dark finds its most intimate relationship with the universe, of almost dissolution, a chamazita, a fiery being, whose interior insists on shining in the dark night. The universe and me. I'm unique. Nothing can divide me without destroying me. I know I am an individual, because I feel it deeply, with an almost painful acuity, even though neurologists tell me about the Self as an evolutionary fiction, structuralists see me as a product of Culture, psychoanalysts as a Family and Marxists as History. item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Li Jie, the 12th century poet and painter, imagined a peaceful place in the midst of nature where, finally available, he could receive as much as he could perceive and feel. In a horizontal scroll he made in 1170, he represented this site of the Fisherman's Pavilion on Mount Xisai, where he would one day actually retreat fourteen years later. This persistent desire for communion with the slow natural world, shared by so many busy scholars, had already led some, many years before, to recreate in cities miniature similes of these places not yet altered by human hands, called penjing, “landscapes in a vase”, where they could observe the mysterious mutation. For others, poets and painters, nothing replaced the experience of being there, in the enclosed space of a garden. In the eighteenth century, to paint a portrait of a personality, to show their character, painters often depicted them in a garden, preferably in their garden. A court painter named Yan Hongzi, active circa 1751–after 1760, in his 1759 portrait of Jingweng (1710–after 1759), a court official, showed him in his garden with the ambiguous name Yiyuan, the "Natural, Proper, Satisfactory Garden" (horizontal scroll, ink on paper, 34.5 x 348 cm, in the Museum Angewandte kunst Frankfurt). And he wrote a comment on it, playing on the ambiguity of the yi sinogram: «I met old Mr. Jingweng of Beihai at the official district office of his boss, Mr. Hu. Our beds were facing each other and we lived together, happily and cheerfully, for a whole month. When the master asked me to make him a painting titled “Yiyuan”, I looked around and said with a laugh: “Isn’t there just in this expression, appropriate satisfaction?” He said: “Appropriate satisfaction like this is already complete satisfaction.” Oh! Although there is nothing for this gentleman that is not adequate satisfaction, he finds natural satisfaction in this garden. That’s why I made this painting of him.” Yan Hongzi would pay another visit to a mythical garden, which in the past gave so much satisfaction to seven wise men. Since the third century, the story has been told of seven literati who took refuge in a bamboo forest, close to the home of one of them, Ji Kang (c.223-262) in Shanyang (present-day Henan). Removed from the hypocrisy and dangers of the world of politics, the seven poets and philosophers, Zhulin qixian, dedicated themselves to the arts. In the horizontal scroll (ink on paper, 33.3 x 67.6 cm, at the Princeton University Art Museum) by Yan Hongzi, they are shown in their Daoist-inspired occupations, writing on the smooth faces of rocks, painting, reciting poetry into the air. At the end of the scroll, walking in the opposite direction, looking back, are two young people with scrolls to write or paint, a pot of wine: the wise men would remain satisfied.

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description:
By Ana Cristina Alves, Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center1 The Taoist philosophy of the beginnings, that of Laozi and the Book of Way and Virtue (《道德经/經》), will choose the water of the ocean and the sea as the privileged image of the Tao (道 Dào), that which cannot be said, without form, on which the universe itself and the ten thousand beings (万物 wânwù) that inhabit it depend, as well as the first principles of existence, the void (無/无 wú), the masculine yang (陽/阳 yáng) and the feminine yin (阴/隂yīn). This choice of an indigenous Chinese philosophy finds its echo in popular language and philosophy, for example in expressions such as “enormous capacity” (海量Hǎiliàng), which can have both an affective and social interpretation of portentous generosity or magnanimity, as well as a physical and concrete one, applying to someone who can ingest large quantities of alcohol. The sea is also linked to the word good and constant, for example in the “oath of eternal love as energetic as the sea and firm as the mountain”, where mountain lends added firmness to the promise (海誓山盟 or 山盟海誓Hǎishì-Shānméng or Shānméng-Hǎishì). The ocean, the sea, but also the great rivers are made up of generous water, both in popular and erudite Taoist philosophy. Here water is the figurative model of the Tao, as read in the Book of Way and Virtue and in the best sinology, which is why we recommend additional reading of Alan Watts Tao: The Watercourse Way. It is worth paying special attention to the chapters in which water appears as the closest representation of the Tao in the Book of Way and Virtue, namely: chapters 8, 14, 34, 66 and 78. In chapter 8 we are informed that the Tao is the supreme good “like water” (上善如水) (Abreu, 2014, 43), but it is not water itself. Therefore, it will be due to the similarity of functions that both are compared. Now water is generous, granting life to all beings, without establishing any distinction between them, its gift reaches even those that no one likes and I am thinking, for example, of parasites. It remains close to the earth to fertilize it, it is deep, simple, true, fair and correct and very timely, when it washes and cleans at the right time. This is also the case with the Tao. In the first verses of chapter XIV, regarding the Tao, an aquatic image appears again:
You look and you don't see, It's called Indistinct. You listen and you don't hear, It's called Silent. Touch and don't get caught, It's called Subtle. This trio is not decipherable For it merges into a unity 2 (Ribeiro, 2004, 32-33) And a little later we are told that he is nameless and uninterrupted (繩繩不可名) (Ibidem) The Tao is like an ocean, an uninterrupted and inexhaustible unity in which someone easily imagines themselves swimming in water that is neither too bright nor too dark, as would happen to Michael Saso in his 14th meditation on the Tao, in A Taoist Cookbook. with Meditations from the Laozi DaodeJing, which he called “Nadar no Tao” (Saso, 1994,47), a meditation that he accompanied by a recipe for spinach, soy paste and sesame, since the wise man is the one who “empties the mind and fills the belly” (虛其心實其復) (Ribeiro, 2004, 10-11), here one feels how the author is immersed in the great Tao, following with the current. Water can also be represented in a large river, as in chapter 34: The great Tao floods like a river, To the left, to the right, Ten thousand beings depend on him. （大道泛兮/其可左右/万物恃之而生） (Abreu, 2013, 94-95) In the same chapter we are told that the Tao not only gives life but nourishes and feeds, being an essential shelter in the return to the origins, not for death, but for eternal life diluted in the great unity, which is why it is great, as big as the sea, or rather the great sea, which is the ocean. Whoever wants to be as it should be in existence or even correctly govern the world, must follow the model of the water in rivers and seas, as we read in chapter 66: Rivers and seas are greater than a hundred valleys Because they remain below them, and so they are princes, dominating waterfalls and streams. (江海所以能为百谷王者/以其善下之/故能为百故王)3 (Abreu,2013, 158-159) The wise man's behavior is distinguished by its malleability and spontaneity. He does not impose himself, which is why he is respected by everyone, only he should then govern, because he acts naturally, without oppressing, without hurting, letting everyone follow their course as freely as possible, as is reiterated in chapter 78: Nothing in the world is more malleable and flexible as for water, but in attacking what is hard and rigid nothing can surpass it and there is nothing to replace it. (天下莫柔弱於水/而攻堅強者莫之能先) (Ribeiro, 2004 160-161) Laozi's Taoist water is among the Five Chinese Elements (Water, Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal) the one that evokes great oceanic unity, source of life for everything that exists, but also of death, or rather, of return to origins and eternal life, when this image represents the philosophical principle Tao. And if water, fresh and salty, is the supreme good of the world, the Tao is the origin, the supreme good, including of Heaven. As a root or mysterious female (chap 6) it is the root of the cosmos as we know and experience it. He is a source of spiritual and material life, but so is water, since his model must be followed in all circumstances, from the material source of beings to complex human conduct. People who act correctly, and especially Taoist sages and saints, are aware of the physical and concrete model of water that helps them practice another invisible one, that of Tao. They will then be malleable and adaptable, capable of nourishing themselves from the inside and giving life to any form on the outside. You will know how to transform yourself to better nourish and vivify. The Taoist oceanic model differs from the one that inspired the Portuguese throughout history, who looked to the sea as their ocean. Taoist water is not challenging nor does it call for conquest, it does not have cables of storm or hope to bend, it does not require weapons or boats, nor maps, nor nautical instruments. It is the dominant, conquering element within all beings, who will adapt to this most malleable element, without needing to develop their inventive spirit. The philosophy it leads to does not ask for vigilance or a critical spirit, but adaptation to the world as it is and generosity to accept it with a minimum of suffering and a maximum of joy. item.title: Julie Oyang
item.description: Interview with James Yanzhao Xing, Chinese private collector living in Xi'an, specializing in Ancient Jade (Archaic Jade) Four years ago, in 2021, James inherited more than 300 pieces of antiques from his elderly father. The family heritage dates back to the Song dynasty (10th-13th centuries) and the collection includes exquisite jade items, porcelain, bronze wares, incense burners and high-value jewelry from various periods. During the turbulent war years, these treasures were buried in a hole in the backyard for decades. Now, through their interdisciplinary curatorial project, they are about to enter a dynamic dialogue with the worlds of fashion, art and sport. Joy: How did you feel when you received the family inheritance? I was completely surprised! My brothers and I had no idea that our family had such things. We were ignorant about our family history. Joy: Tell me about your family history. James: Our original surname was Zhao and we belonged to the imperial family of the Song dynasty. Our roots are in the heart of Chinese civilization. Chinese history has been complicated and turbulent, and my family has failed to preserve the details of our specific ups and downs. All I know is that in 1931, to escape the Japanese occupation, my grandmother took my father and other family members and together they walked to Chongqing in the south. My father was still a boy. To survive and take better care of her son and family, my grandmother decided to remarry into a local clan called the Xing. The Xing family accepted the proposal, as long as my grandmother paid them 300 taels of silver, a significant amount in wartime China. That's how we changed our imperial surname Zhao to Xing. After remarrying, my grandmother asked my father to dig a hole in the yard. That's where the family heirloom was stored, until my father decided to pass it on to me. My father didn't want to divide the collection between my brothers, as he knew I was the only one who could appreciate its true value. To repay my father's appreciation for me, I immediately gave my private collection a name: Jade Ambience, 琼华幸境 in Chinese. Joy: Why that name? James: I feel like I've always been lucky in life, like I've always been protected by some supernatural force with which I could cure strange illnesses and save people. You know, I love helping people and I can't stand seeing sadness and injustice in the world. Since he was a child, he saved lives during the annual floods of the Yangtze River in Chongqing. I didn't fear for my own life, because I knew I was protected. Will it be a gift? I would like to believe so. I even abandoned my career as a successful businessman and decided I wanted to be a soldier, so I could actually contribute to my country instead of earning a lot of money. I even turned down an opportunity to go to the USA and run a company there. That was in 1989. My experiences in the army made me stronger, both physically and mentally. I value life's experiences because they make me understand the human world better and give me positive energy to appreciate each day. In some inexplicable way, I attribute all of this to the jade items in my collection (laughs). JOy: In fact, Chinese people believe that jade stone radiates positive energy. Since ancient times, jade has been associated with protective power, healing power and immortality. What is the true value of your collection, in your opinion? As I said, jade has a very special place in Chinese culture. Jade symbolizes moral integrity and virtue, which is the stone's central symbolic value. Confucianism inextricably linked jade to the ideal of the “exemplary person” (junzi 君子), who should embody the virtues reflected in the physical qualities of jade, including benevolence, righteousness, wisdom, courage (“It is better to be a broken jade than an intact tile”) and purity. Jade served as a material expression of authority and was made into ritual objects used to communicate with divine forces and symbolized imperial power—most notably through the legendary Imperial Seal made of jade. For ordinary Chinese people, jade offers protection and good luck and has long been considered a talisman against evil forces. Jade carvings also carry auspicious meanings: bats for blessings, peaches for longevity, and fish for abundance. In ancient belief systems, jade was believed to preserve the body and soul after death. This concept found its ultimate expression in the jade burial suits of the Han dynasty, intricately assembled from thousands of pieces of jade to ensure immortality. Jade was also seen as the essence of the cosmos—a fusion of the vital energies of heaven and earth. The Chinese language is rich in jade-related expressions that convey admiration and virtue! Therefore, jade items are timeless symbols of love, symbolizing lasting and sincere affection. Today, jade remains a precious heirloom, a solid investment, and a powerful emblem of cultural identity — connecting contemporary Chinese to our heritage. In this way, jade contains old and new life! Jade is not just a precious stone full of vitality. It is a cultural landmark — a bridge between old China and new China. Joy: What do you want to do with your collection? James: Right now, I'm planning to organize a traveling exhibition in Beijing, Shanghai and maybe Macau. As I said before, jade is full of vitality. Jade is a bridge between ancient China and modern China. So I don't want to limit my collection to the usual antique circles. I'm thinking about doing cross exhibitions with fashion, art and sport. I want jade to have a lively dialogue with contemporary, young and modern Chinese audiences!

item.title: Crime | Government does not release data on suicides and attempts
item.description:
After the Health Services, the Security department also stopped publishing data on suicides and attempts, after ten years of publication. The absence was noted in the release of crime data for the months of January to September this year, which show the increase in sexual abuse of minors to almost double
The Government stopped publishing data on suicide cases in Macau, as well as attempts. The absence of these numbers was noted by the newspaper Cheng Pou when it released crime data for the months of January and September this year on Friday. The publication even questions whether “the data on suicide has become ‘the secret that cannot be said’ of the authorities, committed to building a happy Macau”, remembering that this data began to be released in 2015. Highlight is the fact that the Health Services also stopped publishing the statistics, something that was done every three months. In the case of the Security Secretariat, the data was monthly and was broken down by sex, age group and methods used. The lack of numbers comes after Macau broke records in terms of suicide cases in 2024, registering 90 deaths, 2.27 percent more than in 2023. Compared to 2022, the increase was 12.5 percent. Of the 90 cases, 48 ​​concerned male victims and 42 female victims, aged between 12 and 76 years. The most recent data, for the first half of this year, reveals 41 deaths by suicide and 101 attempts. In the release of crime statistics, on Friday, only one case of death by suicide appears in relation to an episode of homicide between brothers, which occurred in August this year, in the north zone. Here, the older brother jumped from the balcony, being suspected of having killed his younger brother due to financial disputes. Break in crime Looking at the crime panorama in general terms, there is a drop of 7.1 percent in the months under analysis, compared to the same period last year. The territory's authorities highlighted the sharp drop in computer crimes. The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, said that the drop is due to the “decreasing trend” of “crimes that attract more attention from society”, including serious violent crime, theft, robbery, fraud and computer crimes. In the first nine months of the year, 187 violent crimes were recorded, which represents a drop of 11 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (210). Thefts, robberies and frauds fell by 7.7, 5.9 and 23.6 percent, respectively. Computer crime, which recorded 770 cases in the first nine months of 2024, showed a decline of 52.1 percent in the period under analysis, with 369 cases. The decline in cases of fraud using telecommunications, cyber fraud and computer fraud, said Chan Tsz King, “reflects the effectiveness of the prevention and combat work carried out by the police, and the significant increase in public awareness about fraud prevention”, he said. The Government also highlighted that crime related to illicit gambling increased by 985 percent between January and September this year, with 394 more cases compared to the same period in 2024. The increase is due to the entry into force, in October last year, of the law to combat illicit gambling crimes, which introduced “the new crime of ‘exploitation of illicit exchange for gambling’ and expanded the scope of coverage of some crimes related to illicit gambling”. For the same reason, said the secretary, gambling-related crimes soared in the first three quarters of 2025 – 1,737 cases, 70.1 percent more than in the same period last year. In the past, the official said, fraud committed by people illegally exchanging money outside casinos “could not be identified as related to gambling”. “However, with the criminalization of ‘illegal money exchange’ and the improvement of legal provisions”, these cases “are now included in gambling crime statistics, thus increasing the number of crimes”, he indicated. More abuse of minors Chan Tsz King, who took office in October and presented the crime report for the first time on Friday, also referred to a 6.1 percent increase in crimes against the person, with child sexual abuse increasing by 86.7 percent, from 15 cases in the first nine months of 2024 to 28 cases in the same period this year. The secretary explained that these are essentially “voluntary sexual acts between people of the same age”, with “transmission of photographs and pornographic images”, without forgetting cases of “less serious sexual harassment”. “Cases involving people with family relationships were also identified, which deserves the attention of society”, said Chan Tsz King, who released data on awareness-raising actions on this problem: more than 70 activities carried out by the police, which saw the participation of more than 12,000 people, including students, guardians and teaching staff. Drug trafficking and sale and drug consumption, in turn, registered an increase of 37.1 percent, with 13 more cases, and 72.7 percent, eight more cases, respectively. According to the secretary's presentation, the 48 cases registered in the three quarters and the respective increase are due to “the discovery of several cases of cross-border drug trafficking through the reinforcement of internal and external police cooperation”, highlighting a case that occurred in September, when 31 kilos of cannabis flower worth 31.77 million patacas were seized. Chan Tsz King said that this was “the biggest case of cannabis smuggling seized in the history of Macau”. Between walls In the case of the crime of rape, there was a decline in the number of rape crimes, to a total of 24 cases, 40 percent less than in the same period of the previous year. The Secretary for Security added that “more than 70 percent of the victims were not residents of Macau”, and “the majority of these crimes occurred in hotel rooms”, while “a number of these involved pecuniary conflicts between the victims and the suspects, and it is not possible to rule out the hypothesis that some of the cases occurred in the context of a sexual transaction”. In this context, the secretary clarified that the police authorities have been “in close communication with the hotel sector”, and “police devices and inspections in peripheral areas of hotels and casinos” have been reinforced. Between January and September, more than 160 police actions were carried out to combat prostitution, with 192 people suspected of engaging in prostitution activity being intercepted. Furthermore, during the period in question, 17 cases of pimping or exploitation of prostitution were resolved, with the arrest of 26 suspects. Silence as always Questioned by Lusa during the press conference about the first case to be investigated in Macau within the scope of national security, the secretary made no comments. “The case (…) is being handled by judicial entities and, due to secrecy, it would not be appropriate for the Secretary of Security to comment”, added Chan Tsz King, who was a Public Prosecutor when former deputy Au Kam San was detained. At the end of July, the territory's police announced the arrest of Au Kam San, the first under the state security defense law, which came into force in 2009, with the scope being expanded 14 years later. The accusation is not yet known and there is no information about who will defend the former deputy. With Lusa

item.title: EU | New target to reduce 90% of pollutants by 2040
item.description: MEPs and countries from the European Union (EU) yesterday reached an agreement on a target to reduce 90 percent of polluting emissions by 2040, with a view to carbon neutrality in 2050, although new forms of flexibility are foreseen. “The co-legislators agreed on a target of a 90 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2040, compared to 1990 levels, with the aim of achieving climate neutrality in the EU by 2050”, is announced in a statement released in Brussels. After several hours of negotiations, the European Parliament and the Council thus reached, this morning, a provisional political agreement (which will have to be confirmed by both) on an amendment to the EU Climate Law, establishing a new intermediate and binding target for 2040, that of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions by 90 percent compared to 1990 levels. Even so, MEPs and countries agreed to introduce new forms of flexibility to meet the 2040 target, “believing that the green transition and European competitiveness must advance hand in hand”, according to the note. Under review Specifically, from 2036 onwards, up to five percentage points of emissions reductions (two more than the Commission's initial proposal) could come from high-quality international carbon credits, compatible with the Paris Agreement. In the case of Portugal, for example, this means that sustainable projects in countries such as Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP) can count towards the Portuguese target. “Thanks to Parliament's insistence, additional safeguards were integrated, including the prohibition of financing projects in partner countries that contradict the Union's strategic interests”, highlights the European assembly. It is up to the European Commission to analyze different options for the role of international credits in future EU climate legislation to reach the 2040 target. Furthermore, the community executive will assess progress every two years, taking into account the most recent scientific data, technological advances and the EU's international competitiveness. "The review will analyze the situation of net removals at European level, comparing it with what is necessary to meet the 2040 target, as well as possible implementation difficulties and the potential to strengthen the EU's industrial competitiveness. Trends in energy prices and their impacts on companies and families will also be considered", according to the European Parliament. This will allow Brussels to modify the 2040 target or take additional measures to strengthen the support framework, for example to protect the EU's competitiveness, prosperity and social stability. Parliament will now vote on the informal agreement and the Council will also have to approve it, with the text coming into force 20 days after its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. The European Climate Law makes each country's effort to reduce its polluting emissions legally binding.

item.title: Europe | Merz considers aspects of Trump's geostrategy unacceptable
item.description: The head of the German federal government, Friedrich Merz, declared yesterday that there are certain unacceptable points in the document on Defense and geostrategy of the North American Administration led by Donald Trump, from a European perspective. “I don’t see any need for Americans to want to save Democracy in Europe,” he said, on a visit to Rhineland-Palatinate (a southwestern state), which is home to several United States of America (USA) military bases. In a strategic document on US national security, released last week, there is a warning about the danger of “civilizational extinction” in Europe if “current trends” continue. Trump, in the preface, summarizes: “we put America first in everything we do”. “It is more than plausible that, in a few decades at most, the members of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization) will become predominantly non-European”, he wrote, adding that “it is legitimate to question whether they will perceive their place in the World or their alliance with the USA, in the same way as those who signed the organization's charter”. The White House regrets European decisions that “undermine political freedom and sovereignty, the migration policies that are transforming the continent [Europe] and creating tensions, as well as the censorship of freedom of expression and the repression of political opposition, the drop in birth rates and the loss of national identities (…)”. Washington expresses the desire for “Europe to remain European, regain its civilizational self-confidence and abandon its fruitless obsession with regulatory suffocation.”

item.title: Australia | Twelve killed in attack during Jewish festival
item.description: At least twelve people died and many injured were transported to Sydney hospitals yesterday, after a shooting attack on the Australian beach of Bondi, while a Jewish celebration was taking place. “There are two people in police custody on Bondi beach”, reported the New South Wales State Police on its X account, which asks “the public to avoid the area”. Citing police sources, the AFP news agency reports that the attack caused ten deaths. The New South Wales ambulance service confirmed to ABC television that at least 16 people were transported to six hospital centers in the region. Several witnesses report that it was a shooting attack carried out by an as yet undetermined number of armed people, but the authorities have not confirmed this information either. A British tourist told French news agency AFP that he saw “two gunmen dressed in black and armed with semi-automatic rifles”. Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has already issued a statement lamenting the “shocking and distressing scenes” coming from Bondi and confirmed the existence of injuries. Part of the beach was the scene of a celebration of the Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which began yesterday and, although Australian authorities have not yet made any connection with the incident, the President of Israel, Isaac Herzog, denounced what he classified as a “vile terrorist attack against the Jews who were lighting the first candles” of the religious festival. "Our heart is with them. The heart of the entire nation of Israel beats strong at this precise moment, as we pray for the recovery of the injured, we pray for them and we pray for those who lost their lives," he said in an official statement.

item.title: East Timor | Memories of a man's life reflect the resistance of a people
item.description: The book “Return to Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” recounts the Timorese's testimonies about the years of Timor-Leste's resistance to the Indonesian occupation. The testimony was written in Macau by former resident and university professor Duarte Trigueiros. 50 years after the occupation, the author reminded HM of the work launched in 2022 This year has been marked by the celebrations of the 50th anniversary of the independence of many former Portuguese colonies. Timor-Leste went to one of these territories. However, shortly after the unilateral proclamation of independence, on November 28, 1975, there was a period of confrontation that culminated in the Indonesian occupation, on December 7 of the same year. This Sunday marks 50 years since the invasion that marked the fate of the young country. In connection with this date, the book “Regresso a Uaidora, the childhood and youth of Domingos Gusmão” was released in 2022, which reveals the story of the Timorese, who was a student in Macau and a student of the author Duarte Trigueiros, former economist and professor at the University of São José. HM spoke to the author about the reflection of the pain and struggle for self-determination of a people that can be seen in the life of a man and his family. "When I was teaching in Macau, I collected the testimony of this Timorese from Baucau. Domingos Gusmão, knowing that he had taught at the National University of Timor-Leste for several years, told me how he and his family lived through all these terrible events." This is how the book was born, with Trigueiros merely reporting the testimony, later corrected in partnership with Domingos Gusmão. The work only has an online version, but at the time of launch it had the support of Fundação Oriente in printing some copies. Matebian, East Timor O contacto de Duarte Trigueiros, que viveu vários anos em Macau, com Domingos Gusmão deu-se na Festa da Lusofonia, em 2015. “Fui à barraca de Timor-Leste e ele disse-me que tinha coisas interessantes para me contar, mas que não conseguia falar bem português, e que gostava de deixar o seu testemunho escrito. A dada altura propus fazer-lhe perguntas a partir da sua infância, como era a vida na aldeia, e assim nasceu o livro, com nove chapters.” The beginning of the work describes, “through the eyes of a child, the day-to-day life of farmers in the Baucau mountains in Timor-Leste, the determination in which they reacted to the invasion of their country in 1975 and the brutal repression that followed”. "The book follows not only his life, but also his family and the few who remained. In the end, there was practically no one left", describes Duarte Trigueiros. According to the work, Domingos Gusmão was born on November 1, 1969 in the village of Uaidora, belonging to the municipality of Baucau, the son of Julião, a farmer, and Juliana, a maid. "But only the place where I was born is correct. The date of birth is nothing more than a conjecture and the names that appear on the certificate as being my parents, Julião and Juliana, are also not those of my real father and mother, but of relatives who adopted me when I was an orphan. In fact, I am the son of Martinho Gusmão, whose code name was 'Maunoco' and he was the chief of the Uaidora village until his death in 1983; and my mother was Ricardina, Martinho Gusmão’s second wife, the one who gave him offspring.” This is how Domingos’ story begins. Going to Baucau The work recounts very difficult years, with thousands of Timorese fleeing into the bush to escape the Indonesians, organizing armed struggle. One of the chapters, highlights Duarte Trigueiros, reports how Domingos and his family "were deported and left without any type of support, without doctors or food. "A huge number of people died at that time, until the beginning of the 80s, and they [Dominicos Gusmão's family], already in the place where they were cultivating the land, began to have fruits from the land, and send children to school. This boy [Domingos Gusmão], during that time, started preparing to go to Baucau to study, something that was not easy, as it was necessary to find a place, and there were many children.” Domingos and Xanana Gusmão It was there that the family decided to leave the village and go to Baucau, finding jobs “at the service of the troops, judges, nurses and doctors”, which gave them their first contacts with the Timorese resistance. "He [Domingos Gusmão] began organizing what they called a clandestine front with his colleagues. The book reports all these adventures that clearly reveal how the resistance worked. This boy then felt the desire to continue his studies and applied to a Catholic seminary", recalled Duarte Trigueiros. The connection to the Catholic religion was not an accident. "The purpose was to go abroad, because the only thing that Indonesians really respected was the Catholic Church, they didn't respect anything else. And he left, spent a number of years training. He was in the Philippines, where he also participated in resistance activities, and returned as a priest, in 2012." Writing this book was important to Domingos Gusmão because he “wanted to mention the names of the [Timorese] commanders of the first phase, when the Indonesian troops entered through Baucau, towards the interior, and there were a large number of resistance commanders who resisted, almost without weapons, and were killed”. “When he spoke to me about this subject, he was very insistent, he told me ‘Write down the name of that commander.’ Everything so that the names would not be forgotten”, he recalled. "What he told me is that nowadays, in Timor-Leste, people are compensating the members of the resistance who are alive, but there are many dead who gave their lives for this and are being forgotten. But this book also talks about everything on a personal level, about what happened to the uncle, how the father died at that stage, thrown to the ground, with a gun butt, with kicks, because he refused to accept an order and they threw him to the ground. He was the head of the village and had to accept the order [of the Indonesians], but he refused”, highlighted Duarte Trigueiros. For the author, the work tells “a truer version” of what the Indonesian occupation was, and very specifically about the experiences of the town of Uaidora and the interior of the country. In the book, you can read Domingos' testimony about this phase of resistance in Baucau, starting in 1986. “I owe my enlistment in the resistance to the clandestine fronts and also to my colleague Domingos de Oliveira. (…) A few weeks later, on the 16th or 17th of September 1991, the centenary of the Dili cathedral was celebrated and young people were invited to participate. 14 left from Baucau. Buses full of teenagers and I was one of them. The next day, during the return trip, FRETILIN flags appeared and we all sang hymns to independence. As we passed through Manatuto, the troops ordered us to stop, but then they told us to continue; and at the entrance to Baucau, before the airport, the road was blocked and we were surrounded by a strong military device. There were only three assault cars!” Gusmão continues his account of this tense moment. "After having cornered us like this, the troops, with the assault vehicles on the right side, occupied the left side. The 14 trucks were lined up with the military device, which had its weapons in position, ready to fire. They were like a very long firing squad. There we stayed, with all those weapons pointed at us, in silence while time passed and nothing happened." Support from Portuguese Duarte Trigueiros and Domingos Gusmão kept in touch, but a stroke took away the Timorese's quality of life. "He hardly responds to my emails. Maybe he has a different outlook on life", confesses the author. Another perspective that the work gives, according to Trigueiros, is the position of the Portuguese authorities during the years of Indonesian occupation, dispelling the idea that there was abandonment after independence. "I simply show what Domingos told me, and he told me that many of the resistance commanders had been Portuguese soldiers and that, therefore, they knew how to use weapons. He also told me that they were extremely patriotic. There is a report that in the 90s they tried to get a satellite phone from Portugal to give to the resistance, and there are references to the support of the Portuguese Embassy in Manila. I think we looked good in the photograph", he concludes. Duarte Trigueiros taught in Timor between 2004 and 2009, where he found higher education very weak. "The students practically didn't know Portuguese and we had to teach in Portuguese. That alone was a huge effort. In general, the students were weak, they were very poorly prepared. The [educational] preparation of the Indonesians had been of a low level, as there was discrimination against students for being Timorese. The book describes this, how only good students had the right to move up, so to speak, and that didn't even mean going to university." Even so, Duarte Trigueiros highlights the training of “a good number of people, engineers, law graduates, economists”. “It took a lot of work and that was the great support that Portugal was able to give”, he added. Today, the former economist says that the Timorese look at the Portuguese with immense gratitude. "It's amazing, because when we go on a street with an Australian, they despise the Australian and don't talk to him, but with the Portuguese they shower him with all kinds of affection. This happens a lot in Timor-Leste", he concluded.

item.title: Evolution | African genomes point to the origins of the human species
item.description: Homo sapiens has existed for at least 300,000 years, but its exact origin remains unknown and a new study has ruled out the hypothesis that it evolved in East Africa and expanded south. The study, based on the analysis of ancient genomes of people who lived from the Stone Age – 10,200 years ago – to 150 years ago in southern Africa, argues that a group of individuals lived in partial isolation for several hundred thousand years. By analyzing their genomes, researchers found genetic adaptations that likely shaped H. sapiens as a species. Details of the study – the most comprehensive to date on ancient African DNA – conducted by researchers from Uppsala University (Sweden) and the University of Johannesburg, were published on Wednesday in the magazine “Nature”, reported the agency Efe. “We have long known that Southern Africa was inhabited (…). We can now demonstrate that Homo sapiens existed and evolved in Southern Africa over a long period and that this region played a significant role in human evolution, perhaps the most important of all”, highlighted Mattias Jakobsson, geneticist at Uppsala University and main author of the study. The team analyzed the ancient genomes of 28 individuals from southern Africa and compared them with those of their contemporaries from other parts of the world. They discovered that the Stone Age inhabitants of southern Africa lived in isolation for a long period. “This group appears to have remained genetically isolated for at least 200,000 years, and it was only around 1,400 years ago that clear traces of genetic flow within this group began to emerge, when DNA from individuals from East and West Africa began to appear in individuals from Southern Africa,” explained Jakobsson. Although no new groups migrated to southern Africa until about 1,400 years ago, genetic data suggests that members of the southern population migrated north during certain climatic periods. In fact, genetic material — dating back to around 8,000 years ago — from this southern population has been found in individuals from present-day Malawi, making it possible that southern migrations also occurred earlier. Techniques and variations A large part of the human remains analyzed were found in the Matjes River Rock Shelter (South Africa), an archaeological site with remains dating back approximately 10,000 to 1,500 years. This site also revealed different tools from each historical period, made with different techniques. However, the individuals are genetically practically identical throughout the entire period, that is, there is no evidence of immigration or population exchange, “exactly the opposite of what happened in Europe, where cultural changes tend to coincide with population migrations”, analyzed Jakobsson. In the study, researchers identified 79 DNA variants unique to Homo sapiens, distinct from those found in Neanderthals, Denisovans, chimpanzees and gorillas. Seven of these variants, related to kidney function, were “clearly overrepresented”. The authors believe that these variants are linked to the unique human ability to cool the body through sweat, which requires a good ability to regulate the body's water balance. They also found variants involved in the immune system and neuronal growth. More than 40 percent of these variants are associated with neurons and brain growth, suggesting a role in cognitive evolution. Additionally, several genes have been linked to attention, a mental ability that may have evolved differently in Homo sapiens compared to Neanderthals and Denisovans.

item.title: Fire in Hong Kong | Considered future of bamboo scaffolding
item.description:
