The fire in Tai Po sparked a debate around bamboo scaffolding, a tradition that was already at risk of extinction due to the lack of new specialized workers. Architect Nuno Soares believes that, before questioning the safety of bamboo, it is necessary to reinforce monitoring of the illegal use of flammable materials
Could an industry already at risk of extinction disappear more quickly than previously thought, due to the tragic fire in Hong Kong? The issue has been raised since, last week, a major fire in a residential complex under construction, in the Tai Po area, resulted in at least 159 deaths, according to the most recent report. The skyscrapers had bamboo scaffolding and other flammable materials used in the construction process. On Friday, Hong Kong authorities concluded that the fire was worsened by flammable bamboo scaffolding and foam insulation panels. Furthermore, Hong Kong fire chief Andy Yeung corroborated what many testimonies interviewed by AFP stated. “We found that the alarm systems in the eight buildings were not working properly,” he said. According to the Lusa agency, the report, still a preliminary expert, concluded that the materials used in works contributed to higher temperatures. “Based on the initial information we have, we believe that the fire started in the protective screen (plastic material to protect against the spread of dust and falling objects) located on the outside of the lower floors (…), and quickly escalated due to the panels” that protected the windows, said the security chief of the neighboring special administrative region, Chris Tang. To HM, the architect Nuno Soares, linked to the study of bamboo construction, and who has fought for its preservation, considers that before pointing blame at the material, it is necessary to reinforce the supervision of the shipyards. "We know that bamboo is difficult to ignite. In other words, bamboo burns, but it is difficult to burn and, when it does, the combustion is slow, and it is easy to fight [a possible fire]. Now when there is a net around it, which is not fireproof, everything catches fire very quickly, right? There is already known data [on the incident], and we know that the scaffolding was, in fact, made of bamboo, but there was a plastic net around it which was not fireproof, in addition to the use of Styrofoam to cover the windows, which is a highly flammable material”, he highlighted. Nuno Soares also referred to the occurrence, in Tai Po, of “problems with the fire detection and fighting system in the building itself, built in the 1980s, and which was already out of date”. “Several problems in inspection are also known, and with the data we have we are unable to conclude, in summary, that bamboo was the guiding principle in this situation, and we have to be rigorous in this type of analysis”, he added. Therefore, Nuno Soares considers that caution is needed and not to enter into simplistic or hasty analyses. “We cannot, with the data we have at the moment, say that bamboo has no responsibility whatsoever.” "If there had been that nylon net around the metal scaffolding, a very similar situation would have happened, because the fire would have spread through that net and then through the Styrofoam on the windows. Fire safety regulations are already quite strict in Macau and Hong Kong, but where I think there is room for improvement is in inspection," he said. A material question The Global Times newspaper wrote on Monday about the difficulties in putting an end to the construction of bamboo scaffolding in a short period of time. In an article entitled “Tradition under fire”, we read that “some defenders argue that bamboo scaffolding, as a traditional construction technique, is low-cost, flexible to assemble and disassemble, and especially suitable for the tight spaces of old urban neighborhoods”, with “contrary voices that focus on security risks”. Quoted by the same newspaper, Lee Kwong-sing, president of the Hong Kong Institute of Security Professionals, said that, given the available information, “the flammable materials on the external walls set fire to the safety nets, not the bamboo itself”. Demonstrating a similar position to Nuno Soares, the person in charge added that “even if metal scaffolding had been used, safety nets would have been necessary, and if flammable materials were not removed, the risk of fire would not change much”. Zhao Shixing, chief engineer of the Sichuan Provincial Institute of Architectural Design and Research, told the Global Times that bamboo's weaknesses lie in its safety and stability, as raw and untreated bamboo has a B2 combustibility rating according to China's standards, and can easily ignite when exposed to other flammable materials. Zhao said, therefore, that “this vulnerability was completely exposed in this fire.” According to the state newspaper, authorities in the neighboring city of Shenzhen had already banned the use of bamboo in 1994, and in January 2022 the country's Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development banned the use of “bamboo (or wooden) scaffolding” in construction and municipal engineering works across the country. Difficult to erase tradition In special administrative regions, the construction of bamboo scaffolding continues to be a reality, despite the alleged lack of younger personnel interested in learning the technique. Nuno Soares highlights that the technique “is very deep-rooted”, having “existed for decades in Macau and Hong Kong”, surviving due to its versatility and being adaptable to local climate conditions. The architect also highlights among the decisive factors for the use of bamboo the “workmanship and type of high-rise constructions that are carried out in Macau and Hong Kong”. In the hours following the accident, Macau authorities carried out a series of inspections of construction sites, in addition to organizing dozens of lectures to raise awareness of the risks of fires. Such a stance was “wise and preventive”. "The bamboo scaffolding was not removed, but the flammable nets that were in several buildings in Macau were removed. What we need to do is more testing, that is, it is not enough to have the manufacturer's certificate saying that the material is fireproof. Inspection must be more rigorous." “One of the reasons why I think bamboo scaffolding has been so successful throughout the recent history of Macau and Hong Kong is because it is safe, in the sense that it resists winds and typhoons well, and protects workers who wear protective elements”, highlighted the architect. In general, Nuno Soares says that “it doesn’t make sense” to have a sudden, total ban on the use of bamboo in the construction of scaffolding. “Taking into account the data we have, this measure of preventing bamboo construction makes no sense.” When the fire was still far from being extinguished, the police had already announced the arrest of three suspects for “gross negligence” after the discovery of flammable materials abandoned during work, which allowed the fire to “spread quickly” due to the strong wind. Investigations continue. Quoted by CNN, Xinyan Huang, associate professor at the University of Hong Kong, declared that bamboo is “definitely a flammable material”. "This season is very dry in Hong Kong, so the possibility of the bamboo burning is very high. Once the combustion takes place, the fire spreads very quickly", he concluded. In a joint note from the Fire Department, Directorate of Land and Urban Construction Services, Directorate of Labor Affairs Services and Institute for Municipal Affairs, on Friday, the Macao SAR Executive said it was “extremely attentive to the serious fire that recently occurred in the neighboring region”, but did not reveal whether or not it will ban the use of bamboo. “After checking fire-fighting equipment, hazardous substance storage management and emergency evacuation routes, they all comply with applicable safety requirements.” Furthermore, and mentioning more recent statistical data, it is stated that “there are currently around 566 construction sites in Macau, of which more than 60 involve works with scaffolding”, with the promise of carrying out “intensive inspections of all works with scaffolding, requiring contractors to strictly comply with their fire prevention responsibilities”. However, the Executive admitted yesterday that it could replace bamboo scaffolding with metal ones, but only if there is “social consensus” between the population and construction companies, said Mak Tat Io, deputy director of Land and Urban Construction Services.

item.title: Light Rail | Public consultation on route in 2026
item.description: The Government plans to move forward with a public consultation on Light Rail planning in the first half of 2026. The information was provided by the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam, on the sidelines of the Charity March. According to Radio Macau's Chinese language channel, the secretary indicated that the consultation will be carried out after the data on the different routes that are being analyzed in a strategic study that is underway has been completed. The plans under study include a Southern Line, which will connect the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge border post to Barra station, passing through Zone A of New Landfills, NAPE, Nam Van and Sai Van. A West Line is also planned, from the port of Qingmao to Barra, and a North Line from Taipa, to connect Zone A of the New Landfills to the Oceano station via landfill zones E, D and C. The plans also include a connection from Seac Pai Van to the entrance to the urban area of ​​Coloane.

item.title: Administration | Sónia Chan will head Identification Services
item.description: The former secretary for Administration and Justice, Sónia Chan, will now head the Identification Services (DSI), TDM said yesterday. If verified, the appointment will represent the return of the current director of Supervision and Public Asset Management Services to DSI, where she was deputy director between 1998 and 2010, when she was called to coordinate the Personal Data Protection Office. According to the public broadcaster, Sónia Chan's appointment as head of Public Asset Supervision and Management Services ends next Saturday, marking the end of her mandate and the transition to DSI. TDM also indicated that Lo Pin Heng, deputy director of Identification Services, will lead the Legal and Judiciary Training Center.

item.title: Government wants to show Macau as an example of ties between civilizations
item.description: Experts from Portugal will participate in the first edition of an international forum that aims to present Macau as “a good example” of the links between different civilizations, said the president of the Cultural Heritage Council, Deland Leong Wai Man, at a press conference. “Macau is a fascinating city to show this harmonious coexistence of different cultures”, defended the person in charge. The event is a Government initiative, organized by the Cultural Institute, with the support of the Chinese Academy of History and the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. The 2025 International Civilization Exchange Forum will take place tomorrow and Wednesday, with 40 government leaders and representatives of international organizations from a dozen countries. Among the guests are experts and academics from Portugal, mainland China, Egypt, Indonesia, Tunisia, Italy, Germany, the United Kingdom and Canada, said the Cultural Institute (IC), in a statement. After a meeting of the Cultural Heritage Council, Maria José de Freitas, an architect based in Macau, confirmed to Lusa that she will be one of the Portuguese experts to participate in the Forum. Freitas is also the president of the international scientific committee of the International Council on Monuments and Sites (ICOMOS) on shared built heritage. connecting link Deland Leong Wai Man recalled that 20 years have passed since the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) classified the historic center of Macau as a World Heritage Site. “Macau’s cultural heritage has its own particularity, Chinese and Western characteristics, some monuments with a fusion of cultures”, highlighted the also president of the IC. In addition to “unique construction elements”, the history of the city, which for more than 400 years was under Portuguese administration, is reflected in “customs, traditions, way of life and even intangible heritage”, defended Leong. “All of this has rich cultural value to share with the world”, said the leader, who also highlighted what she said was Macau’s success in safeguarding its cultural heritage. “Macau can serve as an exchange platform for experts from various countries and serve as a link between different civilizations,” added Leong.

item.title: Japan | Interference in the cancellation of events denied
item.description: The Government denied any interference in the cancellation of at least three concerts with Japanese artists scheduled for Macau and guaranteed that these were solely commercial decisions by the organizers "I think that different parties have their own consideration factors", said, at a press conference, the president of the Cultural Heritage Council, Deland Leong Wai Man. "It is normal to have adjustments regarding concerts or different events. Situations of cancellation due to force majeure, is something common", added on Friday, also the leader of the Cultural Institute. On Tuesday, the Venetian Macau hotel-casino announced the cancellation of a concert by Japanese pop singer Ayumi Hamasaki, on January 10th. This is after Hamasaki's concert in Shanghai on November 29th was cancelled. On Wednesday, a Christmas show, scheduled for December 25th, at another hotel-casino, Studio City, which included the female band Say My Name, which includes the Japanese Hitomi Honda, the group's leader, and Terada Mei, was also cancelled. On the same day, a third show was cancelled, this time by the band Hi-Fi Un!corn, a group that includes Japanese artists, and which was scheduled for December 21st, at a third hotel-casino, Galaxy Macau. Asked by Lusa whether there were instructions from the Government not to hold cultural events with artists from Japan, Leong Wai Man assured that “this is a matter for the commercial sector, it is the organizer's decision”. “I have nothing more to add”, stressed the leader. Even so, Leong defended that the wave of cancellations “will not have a major impact” on the Executive's plan to position Macau as an international city of shows. Several fronts On November 15, Macau asked residents and tourists of the territory in Japan to raise their state of alert, after Beijing advised against traveling to the country following statements by the Japanese leader about Taiwan. The warning from the Tourism Services Bureau came “given that since the middle of this year, the trend of attacks in Japan against Chinese citizens has been increasing”, without citing data or examples. However, the Hong Kong Government did so, citing just one incident in Tokyo, in which two Chinese citizens were attacked by locals in late July. China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a warning advising against travel to Japan due to the deteriorating security environment. The main airlines in Mainland China, Macau and Hong Kong announced full refunds for flights to Japan, following the Government's appeal. The measure was taken at a time when tensions between Beijing and Tokyo worsened again, following statements by Japanese Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi.

item.title: IC | International Civilizational Exchange Forum next week
item.description: On the 16th and 17th of December, Macau will host the first International Civilization Exchange Forum. The two-day event is a Government initiative, organized by the Cultural Affairs Bureau (IC), with support from the Chinese Academy of History and the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. According to the IC, the objective of the event is “to promote humanistic and cultural exchange at an international level, narrate the historical paths of China and the MSAR, establishing Macau as a relevant high-level connection for the country in opening up to the outside world and an important window for exchange and mutual learning between Chinese and Western civilizations”. Over two days, government representatives from various countries and regions, international organizations and national and foreign experts participate in around 20 thematic sessions dedicated to cultural inclusion, innovation and cooperation. Holding the forum is part of Beijing's strategy for Macau to reinforce its role as a promoter of global exchange and “establish an academic platform with international projection, promoting mutual understanding and respect between civilizations and highlighting the value of cultural encounters as a driver of human development”.

item.title: Nam Kwong | Politicians want to preserve Ke Zheng-ping's legacy
item.description: Kou Hoi In, former president of the hemicycle, argues that the spirit of patriotism of Ke Zheng-ping, linked to the Chinese Communist Party and founder of the Nam Kwong company in Macau, must be remembered and maintained. The idea was defended at the conference that marked the 20th anniversary of the death of this personality, who was the great-uncle of the current secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam. According to the Chinese channel Radio Macau, more than one hundred personalities from the social, political and student sectors participated in the event. Kou Hoi In also highlighted that Ke Zheng-ping was a selfless figure, supportive of residents and a defender of the “one country, two systems” principle. According to the new president of the TDM administrative board, Macau has promoted the integration of the territory at a regional level and it is important to train new generations with the fundamental values ​​of patriotism and love for Macau. Leonel Alves, lawyer and Macau member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, recalled that Ke Zheng-ping knew how to create a bridge of communication with the Macau community, which received attention and care from the Central Government.

item.title: Culture | Two more concerts with Japanese artists canceled
item.description: After the cancellation of the concert by Japanese diva Ayumi Hamasaki, a show at Studio City that was to include the girl band Say My Name, which features two Japanese women in the lineup, was also canceled due to “unforeseen circumstances”. The same reason was used to cancel Hi-Fi Un!corn no's concert, which also has Japanese members "Due to unforeseen circumstances, we regret to announce that the 2025 iNKODE TO PLAY Christmas show scheduled for December 25th at the Studio City Event Center has been cancelled. We sincerely apologize for any inconvenience caused by the cancellation and thank everyone for their support of this show." It was in this way that the company promoting the concert justified that after all the South Korean Kim Jaejoong, the American of South Korean origin Nicole and the girl band Say My Name would not perform in Macau, as planned. It is important to note that the most familiar artist of the band, made up of young South Koreans and two Japanese women, is the Japanese Hitomi Honda, more famous than her compatriot and stage colleague Terada Mei. The cancellation of the show by iNKODE Entertainment artists was announced a day after Japanese pop diva Ayumi Hamasaki's concert suffered the same fate in Macau and Shanghai. In fact, the vague justifications for not holding the Say My Name concert in Macau and Ayumi in Shanghai were the same: “unforeseen circumstances”. Another youth band from iNKODE Entertainment, with Japanese members, had a fan meeting scheduled for noon on December 6th in Shanghai. The meeting was canceled two hours before the start due to “unforeseen circumstances” The cancellation of the iNKODE Entertainment artists' event in Macau was commented on social media as an example of the “Ayumi effect”. Carbon paper “Due to unforeseen circumstances, CQ (Macau) Entertainment regrets to announce that the Hi-Fi Un!corn ASIA Tour 2025 “Teenage Blue” show in Macau, originally scheduled for December 21st at Galaxy Macau's G Box, has been cancelled.” The cancellation of the concert by Hi-Fi Un!corn, who also have Japanese artists in the group, was announced on Wednesday, increasing the number of concerts in Macau that will not take place due to “unforeseen circumstances”. The communications repeat the same formula of apologies for the inconvenience and instructions to request refunds. It all started when the Venetian Macau announced on Tuesday afternoon that Japanese pop queen Ayumi Hamasaki's concert had been cancelled. Although no justification was given, the cancellation did not surprise fans, who were already anticipating taking a stance after the same thing happened in Shanghai on November 29th.

item.title: General and surreal strike
item.description: A couple who are members of a union belonging to CGTP-Intersindical found themselves in a dilemma on the 11th, the day of the general strike, before leaving home. The problem was wanting to go to the demonstration organized to protest against the absurd proposal of the Montenegro Government regarding a possible new Labor Law, a general strike that had not brought together the UGT and the CGTP for many years. The dilemma was precisely related to the general strike. The couple, residing in Amadora, did not have any transport to travel to the center of Lisbon. His best neighbor had also decided not to go to the demonstration because the Metropolitano was on full strike. Thousands of workers were prevented from going to the demonstration due to lack of transport. Surrealism was in sight. The desire to protest, yes. Like, impossible. More surreal was the fact that the drivers of dozens of buses that the union centers rented to transport protesters had to work on a day of general strike, political Portugal is actually divided in half. On the one hand, conservatives and neo-fascists. On the other, the democratic and radical left. A sad division for those who want a better country and a reduction in the number of Portuguese living on the edge of poverty. The union centrals announced that the general strike was resounding, the best ever and with an unusual turnout of around 80 percent. The strike paralyzed air, rail, road, sea and river transport, as well as schools, daycare centers, hospitals, health centers, homes for the elderly, day centers, courts, universities and museums. The Montenegro Government came, with an air of contempt and arrogance for carrying out the general strike, to say that participation was low and that it would not have exceeded five percent. And his demagoguery prevailed when he “ordered” the television channels he controls to clearly show that at Autoeuropa there were a lot of workers not joining the general strike. The custom of numbers. For some, excellent. For others, a fiasco. The truth is that the general strike affected thousands of Portuguese people, in one way or another. The most important thing wasn't even the general strike. What is at stake is the widespread protest, including by some former PSD and CDS leaders, against the absurd and harmful content of the government proposal for a new Labor Law. The concern that has grown the most in company surveys is the lack of workers, many areas of activity face serious difficulties with the lack of qualified personnel and limitations on the recruitment of foreign labor, putting the objectives of the PRR at risk. In a context of labor shortages, real wages have grown in recent years above inflation, particularly in the construction sector, with appreciations above eight percent. Faced with this scenario, what did the Government decide in its ideological fury? Opening an incomprehensible social conflict around labor laws, which have already been profoundly revised several times this century. Nothing has been noticed about the Government's negotiating openness regarding the main themes of its proposal. Obviously, after four months of the Government turning a blind eye, a general strike had to be organized. A setback in labor pacifism is that the Government intends to allow for the possibility of dismissal without due process or just cause in companies of up to 50 workers, with the exemption from reinstatement if the dismissal is considered illegal by the court, the possibility of hiring in outsourcing the day following the collective dismissal, with an individual time bank, with a fixed-term contract for life, with the possibility of professional reclassification with a salary reduction, with the obligation for the children's parents to work on the weekends or with the decriminalization of undeclared and paid work under the table. These are some of the Government's “innovative” proposals, which at no time agreed to back down, but which in no way contribute to competitiveness, digital modernization and worker qualifications. After months of hypocrisy in dialogue and innocent lamentations about an “untimely” strike, Montenegro came to mix the threat about compliance with minimum services, and the terrible economic impact of the general strike. Simply nonsense with a wave of demagogy of promises about salaries that wouldn't even remind the unions of requests from Santa Claus... Even Bagão Félix and Silva Peneda have already recognized the inopportunity and unbalanced nature of the reform of labor legislation. And these personalities are not trade unionists or socialists, much less attended protest demonstrations or participated in strikes. The most surreal thing about all this is that the Government will hope that after having forgotten the general strike and after Christmas, it will be able to impose the crushing machine that will lead to Portuguese workers losing rights like they never dreamed of. All that remains is for the PSD/Chega alliance to announce that the democratic regime will also be the target of a labor reform…

item.title: A tour of Macau
item.description: Every year, following the presentation of the Lines of Government Action, the SAR Government holds debates in the Legislative Assembly on the various areas of governance, where those responsible answer questions from deputies. But to truly understand the current situation in Macau, first-hand experience and knowledge are undoubtedly essential. It is said that an old electrical appliances store located on Rua das Estalagens will close because the owner is retiring. All branches of this store closed at the same time. They are offering 50 percent discounts, which attracts a lot of customers. Faced with strong competition from online sales websites and applications, even supermarkets are starting to adopt this system. Reducing staff is a way of maintaining the business, but what skills does an unemployed supermarket worker have that would allow him to get a job in other areas of the commercial sector? Buying food in person is undoubtedly the best option, but the atmosphere at the Taipa municipal market on Sunday is very different from that on Rua do Cunha, which is packed with people. Some municipal market stall owners even chose to close temporarily. Tourists will certainly not buy products at the market and then go and cook. And the inhabitants of Macau, where did they go? A resident of Taipa told me that since the Macau authorities granted motor vehicle access from Macau to Hengqin Island, people have stopped going to the local market and started shopping in Hengqin, then refueling their cars and having dinner there, simply because everything is cheaper. Given the strong competitiveness of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, going shopping and dining in Zhuhai or Hengqin has become an irreversible trend. In addition to reducing taxes or reducing property rental fees, what effective measures has the SAR Government taken to reduce other operating costs, break monopolies and open the market? The busy atmosphere of Macau's tourist areas during the day makes quiet nights in Zone A of the New Urban Landfills seem somewhat lonely. Public housing projects are being completed one after another, but the various infrastructures around the housing complex are still under construction. To survive, humanity needs a roof, but also a quality of life. The recent improvement measures taken by the Land and Urban Construction Services Bureau can be considered a response to the needs of residents, but “closing” the gaps and improving traffic conditions in Macau is the responsibility of the competent authorities. With the closure of the satellite casinos, the situation of surrounding businesses and the reintegration of affected employees has once again become a topic of debate in the Legislative Assembly. Due to the change in the type of tourists in recent years, nowadays we mostly have those who take selfies and photographs of tourist attractions. The increase in the number of tourists is not proportional to the increase in tax revenue. The question is this, besides the landmarks, the food and the casinos, what else is there in Macau that could entice tourists to spend their money? The grass at the Taipa Jockey Club has grown, the development of the “Parque Oceanis” theme park is still in the planning phase, and construction projects on the land of the Macau Greyhound Racing Company (Yat Yuen) are expected to begin soon. But with a lot of unused land, how will Macau be able to manage its overall development, and furthermore, actively integrate itself into the national development framework? After the debates on the various areas of governance in the Legislative Assembly are concluded, it would be a good time for the main government officials to take a walk through the various areas of Macau without prior arrangements and without an entourage.

item.title: Lessons from 2025 for the decade
item.description: “In a year of converging crises and recalibrated ambitions, 2025 taught the world that resilience is not merely endurance, but the capacity to adapt, reimagine, and act with foresight across economic, political, environmental, and technological frontiers.” Margaret Atwood The year 2025 will go down in contemporary history as a period of intense transformation, marked by events that crossed multiple dimensions of international life and that required an unprecedented capacity for adaptation from States, institutions and societies. On the economic front, there was a global slowdown that reflected the accumulated effects of restrictive monetary policies, trade tensions and geopolitical instability. World growth was around modest values, insufficient to meet the needs for social inclusion and reduction of inequalities. The transition from the cycle of rising interest rates to gradual cuts brought some relief to financial conditions, but also revealed structural weaknesses, with emerging markets facing fiscal and exchange rate restrictions that limited their room for maneuver. Latin America experienced insufficient expansion to generate sustainable employment, while Africa continued to struggle to diversify its economies, which were excessively dependent on commodities. Asia maintained industrial and technological dynamism, but China faced the challenge of stimulating domestic consumption and correcting structural imbalances that had become more evident. No plano político, o regresso de Donald Trump à presidência dos Estados Unidos em Janeiro constituiu um dos acontecimentos mais marcantes do ano. A sua agenda voltou a ser dominada pelo lema “America First”, com medidas proteccionistas, expulsões em massa de imigrantes irregulares e o desmantelamento de sectores do governo federal. Estas acções geraram contestação judicial e acentuaram a polarização política interna, com a utilização da Guarda Nacional em cidades governadas por democratas e ataques aos meios de comunicação a reforçarem a percepção de erosão institucional. No plano internacional, Trump intensificou a actividade diplomática, com resultados variáveis, mas conseguiu protagonizar um papel central na trégua precária alcançada em Gaza, após dois anos de guerra entre Israel e o Hamas. Este cessar-fogo permitiu a libertação de reféns e prisioneiros, bem como o aumento da ajuda humanitária, embora insuficiente segundo a ONU, e deixou em aberto a questão delicada do desarmamento do Hamas. Instability in the Middle East was worsened by Israeli attacks on Iranian nuclear installations, which triggered a twelve-day war between the two countries, with American bombings in Iran. In September, Israel carried out unprecedented operations against senior Hamas leaders in Doha, Qatar, increasing regional tension. At the same time, the United States intensified military actions in the Caribbean and the Pacific, justified as combating drug trafficking, but criticized by the UN as extrajudicial executions. These operations, which resulted in dozens of deaths, highlighted the American willingness to project military power beyond the Middle East, reinforcing the perception of unilateralism and international contestation. On a geopolitical level, Russia's invasion of Ukraine continued to have repercussions, with sanctions and energy tensions affecting Europe. The prolonged conflict maintained instability in the region and reinforced the need for energy diversification, accelerating the transition to renewable sources. In Sudan and other African regions, internal wars have worsened humanitarian crises, with millions displaced and state systems collapsing. International cooperation revealed weaknesses, with difficulties in revitalizing multilateral mechanisms and ensuring predictability in trade flows. On an environmental level, the impacts of climate change have become increasingly evident. Heat waves devastated Asia, floods hit Brazil, Indonesia and parts of Europe, wildfires devastated Canada and hurricanes like Helene and Milton wreaked havoc in the United States. These phenomena exposed the urgency of the energy transition and reducing dependence on fossil fuels. The decarbonization of the economy was recognized not only as an environmental requirement, but as an economic opportunity, with investments in clean energy, sustainable mobility and energy efficiency generating jobs and positioning countries as leaders in the new green economy. The World Economic Forum identified armed conflicts, extreme weather events and geo-economic clashes as the main risks for 2025. The combination of these factors revealed the need for coordinated and strategic action. The regulation of emerging technologies has become a central topic, with debates on data protection, responsible innovation and systemic risks. The absence of clear global standards has increased asymmetries and digital insecurity, especially in areas such as cryptocurrencies, artificial intelligence and digital platforms. Regional comparisons reveal significant disparities. In the United States, growth was around 2.1%, reflecting gradual cuts in interest rates and protectionist policies. Inflation fell to values ​​close to 3%, but domestic consumption remained fragile. In the European Union, average growth was 1.3%, with Germany investing around 40 billion euros in energy transition programs and France reinforcing its commitment to nuclear energy. Portugal recorded growth of 2.1%, supported by tourism, which recovered to record levels, with more than 30 million visitors and revenues exceeding 62 billion euros, representing around 21.5% of GDP, although it faced persistent inflation in food products. In Latin America, Brazil grew 2.4%, but faced severe floods that affected more than 3 million people and caused economic losses estimated at 15 billion dollars, despite inflation remaining at around 5%. Argentina recorded growth of 5.5%, with inflation close to 30%, well below levels above 100% in previous years, reflecting fiscal and monetary stabilization policies. In Africa, average growth was 3.5%, but uneven, with Nigeria and Angola vulnerable to volatile oil prices and Sahel countries experiencing humanitarian crises worsened by desertification and armed conflicts. In Asia, China grew around 5%, below official targets, reflecting the need to stimulate domestic consumption. India recorded robust growth of between 7.5% and 8%, driven by investments in digitalization, renewable energy and tax reforms, remaining the fastest growing economy globally. Thus, the economic outlook for 2025 confirms strong regional disparities. The economies of the United States and European Union grew modestly, while India and China led global expansion. Argentina stood out for stabilizing after years of hyperinflation, and Brazil faced severe climate shocks. Africa maintained positive average growth, but marked by structural inequalities and humanitarian crises. The social impacts were profound. In the United States, immigrant expulsion policies have affected hundreds of thousands of families. In Europe, the increase in energy costs sparked demonstrations in countries such as France and Italy. In Brazil, floods destroyed entire communities, forcing the relocation of more than 500,000 people. In Africa, water scarcity has intensified internal migration. The domestic consumption crisis in Macau reflected the decline in purchasing power of Chinese tourists and the retraction in local demand, directly affecting sectors such as restaurants and commerce. Environmental policies gained prominence. The European Union reinforced the European Green Deal, investing more than 100 billion euros in renewable energy and sustainable mobility. Canada launched reforestation programs that covered 1 million hectares. Brazil sought to implement flood management policies with investments of 10 billion dollars. China has invested in energy storage technologies, with projects valued at US$50 billion. India has expanded solar programs in rural areas, providing electricity to millions of people. In the technological field, artificial intelligence and digitalization have transformed economies and societies. Between 2026 and 2030, more than 50% of administrative tasks could be automated, creating new employment challenges and requiring retraining policies. The use of cryptocurrencies and digital financial technologies could reach more than 500 million active users. Global regulation of artificial intelligence and digital platforms will be essential to prevent market abuse and systemic risks. Countries like Japan and South Korea will move forward with strict legislation, while Europe will seek to lead the way in creating global standards. In the education sector, digitalization and inclusion will be priorities. By 2030, more than 70% of schools in developed countries will be able to use digital platforms for hybrid teaching. Artificial intelligence will be used to personalize learning, adapting content to students' individual needs. However, inequalities will persist in Africa and parts of Latin America. Technical education and continuing training will be essential to prepare workers for new market demands. (Continues)

item.title: Other types of wounds
item.description: The Hung Fuk Court fire in Tai Po, Hong Kong, remains on the agenda almost ten days after it broke out. At the time of writing this article, there were 159 fatalities and 79 injuries, with 31 people still missing. Before we continue, let us once again mourn these deaths and hope that the injured make a speedy recovery. Hong Kong Government data indicates that 79 people were injured in the fire. However, in reality, there may be another type of injured person who is not hospitalized, but who is among us. They deserve our concern and care in the same way. Recently, a story circulated online about a woman who had overheard the conversation of one of the firefighters who fought the fire at Hung Fuk Court. The firefighter was very young and spoke informally, but his description of the fire was terrifying. He said they had to run from the ground floor to the 22nd floor in 10 minutes, transporting injured people across six floors which required excellent physical fitness. Meanwhile, he saw burning corpses and people who had lost legs and arms. Recalling the rescue efforts, he told how he used a crowbar to open doors, to save people who were trapped. However, it was impossible to open some doors with a crowbar. In a race against time and the fury of the fire, he had to give up trying to open those doors and move on to the next ones, fighting to save the survivors. He didn't have time to think about whether there were survivors behind the doors that couldn't be opened. He had even less time to think about the consequences that these survivors would suffer. All these situations caused this young firefighter an enormous feeling of pity and guilt. A mental health professional highlighted that rescue teams often face enormous pressure. If they blame themselves for not being able to help survivors, they may develop Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). They may experience intense fears, helplessness and terror. Those who work in rescue teams may have very distressing recurring memories or dreams, or experience intense psychological or physical suffering triggered by similar situations. Although the anguish they experienced while rescuing the injured is not immediately apparent, it will gradually come to light after the operations are completed. Without proper intervention, they will become another type of victim of the Hung Fook Court fire. The Hong Kong Government provides strong psychological support to rescue teams to alleviate the pressure they are under. However, to further reduce this psychological pressure, it is necessary to improve their mental resilience and raise public awareness of the difficulties of rescue operations. To strengthen the mental fortitude of rescue teams, it is first necessary for them to understand that their work confronts them with disasters and death. These misfortunes and the pressure to which they are subject are not the result of their personal choices and do not happen because they did something wrong. Their lives do not necessarily mean they have to face misfortune and death. Therefore, after work they cannot take them home. Only in this way can they avoid becoming overwhelmed by the pressure. They also have to understand that only by freeing themselves from the traumas they have experienced can they safeguard and share a normal family life with their loved ones. Taking home the misfortunes and pressure will not only affect them but will also unduly affect their families, ultimately generating more tragedy and turning rescuers into victims. Secondly, there are countless jobs, but none are more meaningful than those that save lives. Rescuing victims of disasters from danger, allowing them to remain alive and unharmed, does not simply imply saving them from death; It also involves ensuring that they return home to their loved ones, thus saving the entire family. First responders earn the love and respect of victims, their families and the entire community — a recognition that transcends monetary values. A perfect example, as seen in the news, is that of a middle-aged woman, in her fifties, who, after receiving a phone call from her husband informing her of the fire, immediately left the building. However, without hesitation, he went back and knocked on his neighbor's door to warn him that he needed to escape. The neighbor listened to him, fled and survived, while the woman ended up dying in the flames. The last message he sent to his son was, “Dinner will be ready a little later today.” Who would have thought that this would be the last message he sent to his son? In an interview, the husband said he understood and accepted his wife's actions because he knew she had acted correctly. Why did this woman act correctly? Why is altruism a good thing? The answer is very simple. As long as a person harbors love and integrity in their heart and does their best to help others, they will feel comfort and humanity. If those who were helped reciprocate in kind, then society will be filled with love and there will no longer be conflicts. A peaceful and caring society can be established where people support each other. The love manifested by the fireman and the middle-aged woman is precisely the love that derives from altruism. Let’s express this feeling with a classic line from a Hong Kong film from the 90s “He doesn’t weigh me down, he’s my father” (新難兄難弟) “Everyone for me and I for everyone.” Only when rescuers understand this principle can they understand the deeper meaning of their rescue work and reduce the pressure they carry. To reduce pressure on these workers, public recognition and respect are crucial. The public must understand the difficulties and hardships of rescue work and cooperate actively. A simple tribute and sincere respect are worth more than emotional support. Hopefully this article will help reduce the psychological pressure on everyone involved in the rescue operations at Hung Fuk Court in Tai Po. The public's love, respect and recognition for rescuers is the greatest reward for the immense pressure they suffered and the sacrifices they had to make, which will thus alleviate their psychological trauma. Legal Consultant of the Association for the Promotion of Jazz in Macau Associate Professor of the Faculty of Management Sciences of the Macau Polytechnic University

item.title: China Arts Fund | Selected Macau projects
item.description: The list of candidates selected for financial support from the China National Arts Fund (General Projects) for the year 2026 will include 13 projects submitted by artistic institutions, higher education institutions, companies and artists in the Macao SAR, the Office of the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture announced on Saturday. This is the fifth time that Macau's artistic and cultural projects have been selected for the national financing plan. The central authorities began to allow applications from Hong Kong's special administrative regions from 2021. In a statement, the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, thanked the motherland for the recognition and support given to the development of Macau's arts and culture and warmly congratulated Macau's authors. The selected projects include dance performances, Chinese opera, paintings celebrating nationalism, a musical and creative talent training programs from the Hou Kong Dance Association, Macau University of Science and Technology and City University of Macau. In 2022, nine Macao SAR projects were selected for the first time and the following year 11 applications were distinguished. For the years 2024 and 2025, 10 projects were financed per year, while next year the support will cover the largest number of projects.

item.title: CCM | “Operação Oops! – A Musical” with tickets on sale
item.description: Tickets for a new show taking the stage at the Macau Cultural Center (CCM) have been on sale since yesterday. This is “Operation Oops! A Musical”, selected within the scope of the “Commissioning of Performing Arts Productions 2024-2026” program, and is a comedy that will be presented in three shows, from January 31st to February 2nd. Adapted from the novel of the same name by local playwright Lawrence Lei I Leong, this new production brings together artists from the region to bring to life a score composed by Golden Horse winner Leon Ko. The cast is led by Jordan Cheng, a multi-award winning performer from Macau, honored as Best Actor at the 31st Hong Kong Theater Awards, and the show is directed by Fong Chun Kit, one of the creative minds of the Hong Kong Repertory Theatre. The choreography is designed by local dance creator Florence Cheong, highlights a note from the Cultural Institute. “Operation Oops!” tells the award-winning story of a group of misfits who, disappointed by exorbitant rent prices, come up with a desperate and absurd plan. Thwarted by a series of unfortunate but amusing mishaps, the zero-budget mission goes headlong into a chaotic spiral.

item.title: Portuguese Bookstore | “Macau’s Reflections – Now and Then” until the end of the month
item.description: Until the end of the month, Livraria Portuguesa hosts the exhibition “Macau’s Reflections – Now and Then”, by Pedro Ramos, a photographer closely linked to the territory, where he lived as a child. In this exhibition, we observe his particular look behind the lens on a territory undergoing great change, taking as a starting point the book by journalist José Pedro Castanheira, “Macau – The Last Hundred Days of the Empire” December is always a month of memory. It was in that month that Macau changed course and came under Chinese administration from December 20, 1999, becoming the Macau Special Administrative Region (SAR). As a reminder of this historic moment, but not only that, the exhibition “Macau’s Reflections – Now and Then” will be on display until the end of the month, at Livraria Portuguesa. The initiative, organized and curated by 10 Marias – Associação Cultural, showcases the work of photographer Pedro Ramos. According to a note, this is a project that “offers a deep and sensitive look at Macau at a decisive period in its history: from the transition from the end of Portuguese administration to integration into China, from 1999, to the present day”. The exhibition is a “reflection and a very personal look at Macau”, capturing “the essence of a city in flux, visually preserving its unique hybrid character”. Here, photographs “function as a portal to the past, documenting the historic architecture, vibrant markets, daily street life and cultural traditions that defined Macau in the twilight of its former status”. However, this exhibition is also “a portal to a ‘colorful’ future”, being, for the 10 Marias, an “aesthetically captivating work” and which serves “as a historical and cultural record of inestimable value, highlighting the delicate balance between tradition and modernity”. The exhibition is born from the book Born in 1976, Pedro Ramos lived in Macau, where he completed primary and secondary education. After graduating in photography in Portugal, Pedro Ramos was looking for work in the field, until he came across the opportunity to collaborate on the book “Macau – The Last Hundred Days of the Empire”, written by journalist José Pedro Castanheira, who was in the territory to write a report on the passage of testimony from Portugal to China. "Some were published in the book, others were not. I kept this photographic archive of the last days of the Portuguese presence in Macau. Since the beginning of 2000, I only returned to Macau in 2024, I went on vacation, and as I always carry the camera I decided to cover what I like about Macau, but in more modern times", he confessed to HM. A contact with Mónica Coteriano, founder of 10 Marias, was enough to bring this project out, reflected “in the desire to show a little of the before and after” of the territory. Even so, Pedro Ramos explains that this is not “a comparative exhibition of the before and after of a certain area, or building, it is not a comparative work in which people see a photograph of the before and after”. "The exhibition is organized with a large set of images from the time of the transition, in 1999. On the opening day I felt that these were the photographs that most touched most of the people who were present, because they were able to see a Macau that no longer exists in the same way. There is then a part with photographs taken on my return", he highlighted. Pedro Ramos says he always returns to the places where he was happy, and here there are “many visual parallels”, particularly with more iconic places such as Hotel Lisboa and Ruínas de São Paulo. Reviewing images, looking again at some moments and organizing this exhibition constituted “one of the great challenges”. “I had all the work from 1999 printed, and it was difficult to look at some of the images and, on the one hand, there was a very sentimental act, but it was good to be able to travel back in time a little.” Pedro Ramos highlights a “very strong and striking” photograph, from when the old Macau High School had been transformed into a military base. "Even today, when I look at the image, I feel strange. I'm not saying it was difficult, but it was strange, and it's an image that tells me a lot." Link with Macau Despite having lived part of his childhood and adolescence in Macau, Pedro Ramos has maintained an emotional bond with the territory since those years. "I always feel like I'm back home and I can say that I feel Macau, because I grew up in Macau and lived there for an important period. When people ask me how I see the changes, I say that for those who have known Macau for 30 or 40 years like me, the center of Macau hasn't changed that much. The red market, the Ruins of São Paulo, the Lou Lim Ieoc garden, are places that continue to be very familiar and remain similar. I think that, in that sense, Macau continues to be very just like the city I knew, although it’s bigger and more modern.” Pedro Ramos also said that the exhibition could last a little longer in Macau, with plans to extend it to Portugal. "I'm trying to present this work in Portugal, but I haven't started the necessary contacts yet. I was encouraged to do this because the Macanese community living in Portugal is large and many people, who heard about the exhibition, felt sorry for not being able to see it." Also noteworthy is the fact that the images are available for sale.

item.title: IN SITU | Six installations to think about the use of public spaces
item.description: It’s called “IN SITU Placemaking Biennale” and, until Sunday, it brings different perspectives on the use of public spaces in Macau, in places such as Pátio da Claridade or Praça Ponte e Horta. The CURB – Center for Architecture and Urbanism initiative presents, starting today, workshops and six installations: “Letters to Macau”, “UnPlan”, “Multi-Place”, “Resonatorium”, “Furniture Where Life Begins” and “Where Time Crystalizes” In a small territory like Macau, where tourists and the local population wander between history and the daily glare, it is not always possible to imagine other uses of the public space common to all. But this is precisely what CURB – Center for Architecture and Urbanism – proposes, with a new biennial. The “IN SITU Placemaking Biennale” takes place between today and Sunday, featuring six installations developed by local architects or artists, as well as workshops aimed at connecting the public with these projects. The program is varied, but the six installations focus on the oldest area of ​​the Macau peninsula. After a period of submitting projects, not only from Macau, but also from abroad, the IN SITU curator decided on “Letters to Macau”, presented at Travessa do Aterro; “UnPlan”, in Largo de Santo Agostinho; “Multi-Place”, which can be seen in Largo do Lilau; “Resonatorium”, near Ponte e Horta square; “Furniture Where Life Begins”, in Largo do Aquino; and “Where Time Crystalizes”, in the old Pátio da Claridade. What this biennial proposes is to explore the concept of “placemaking”, that is, the debate around the various options for planning and managing public spaces. According to a note from CURB, this is a “pioneer project” that is not “just a festival”, but rather “a conversation that involves the entire city”. “Placemaking” is nothing more than a theory around the ideas of improving the management of public space with a multifaceted approach, in which the idea is that everyone sits down and discusses what is best for a given place or what could be done in the face of a less good reality. During this weekend, IN SITU aims for “Macau's iconic streets and squares to become a living canvas for design, dialogue and collective imagination”, with the six installations that “will connect and activate iconic public spaces”, transforming them into “spaces to gather, reflect and interact”. Local projects and beyond The biennale was officially inaugurated yesterday, but it only opens its doors today with various activities. The sessions start at 10:30 am with “Where Time Crystalizes”, in Pátio da Claridade, followed, from 11 am, by a “placemaking” activity, in the same place, entitled “Time Crystal Lab”. In the case of this installation, it was developed by a local team, coming from the master's program in Communication Design at the Faculty of Humanities and Arts of the Macau University of Science and Technology. This is a group composed of Lei Mei Ian, Wang Shumeng, Jiang Xintong and Xu Huiyao. “Where Time Crystalizes” is an installation “composed of nine mirrored crystalline shapes and an undulating carpet that evokes a river of time”, with each crystal containing photographs, video fragments and everyday objects, collected in Jason Lei’s documentation about the neighborhood, even before the residents left. Furthermore, in this installation, the exterior parts “reflect the current street and passersby, while the enclosed interiors invite viewers to peek at traces of the past”. The aim of this work is to lead “viewers to feel the flow of space and the sedimentation of memory”, promoting “reflection on the transformation of Pátio da Claridade, from an inhabited community to an empty space, reconsidering the relationship between people, place and time”. This afternoon, from 3:30 pm, “Multi-Place” will be performed at Largo do Lilau, written by Yik Sze Wong, from Hong Kong. This installation presents itself as “a spatial experience in response to urban change”. "How can we question and renew established models of public spaces? And how can we encourage the public to participate more actively in the construction and practice of these spaces? For a long time, the planning and distribution of public spaces were predominantly led by designers. However, cities are dynamic and constantly evolving organisms", describes the biennial organization. With “Multi-Place” it is proposed to “explore how public spaces can respond effectively to dynamic changes in urban activities and the needs of their use”, and the installation aims to serve “as an experimental ground to explore new forms of public spaces, seeking to use flexible spatial models to stimulate community interaction”. Explore the historic center Tomorrow, the day of the biennial also begins at 10:30 am, but this time with the presentation of “Resonatorium”, in Porto Interior, an installation by Lau Josephn On King and Lawrence Liu. Being a local team, but with connections to Hong Kong, in “Resonatorium” the duo decided to be inspired by “the echoes and reverberations inside the churches, as well as the historical image of the wooden chapel that once stood on the site of the Church of São Lourenço”. It is, therefore, a work that “builds a resonance belonging exclusively to the past and present of the site”, being composed of wooden sound modules, “forming a semi-open architectural space, in which the structure itself becomes a resonant body”. The sounds and structure carry symbolism linked to the Church of São Lourenço, the Porto Interior pier, the Largo de Santo Agostinho neighborhood, Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro, without forgetting “the future of Macau”. Saturday afternoon is reserved for an installation from Portugal, “UnPlan”, by the FAHR 021.3 studio, created by Filipa Frois Almeida and Hugo Reis. From 3:30 pm onwards, this temporary installation “designed to offer a new perspective on public space” can be visited, being inserted “in a dense urban fabric, marked by circulation, surveillance and routine”. In this way, it is a “piece that introduces a moment of pause, like an object that is simultaneously familiar and strangely out of place”, in which “instead of prescribing behavior, it proposes an open surface that invites new ways of planning, occupying and imagining”. Sunday is the day to explore “Letters to Macau”, an international project by Chaal Chaal Agency (CCA), a design and research collective founded by architects and researchers Kruti Shah, from India, and Sebastián Trujillo-Torres, from Spain. Here we intend to reinterpret “the city’s traditional mailbox as an urban device for reflection, correspondence and civic imagination”. Describing the organization of the biennial, “Letters to Macau” is inspired “by Macau’s stratified spatial vocabulary, with lunar doors, courtyards, alleys and garden passages, to create a structure that is simultaneously familiar and reinvented”. In this way, “visitors are invited to write letters addressed to the city, sharing memories, wishes or proposals for renewal”, and “each letter is deposited in the structure, accumulating throughout the Biennale and gradually transforming the installation into a collective civic archive”. This installation was built from ten CNC-cut plywood panels, with the structure manufactured using simple and reversible methods, such as fitting, clamping and stacking, which allow for quick assembly, disassembly and reuse. “Its interconnected plans generate different degrees of openness and closure, framing longitudinal and transversal views in response to the narrow verticality of the urban fabric of Porto Interior”, it is further described. In addition to the six central installations, this biennial features several complementary events. This afternoon, between 4pm and 5pm, the “Pressed Echoes of the Inner Harbor – Urban Flora Workshop” will take place at Ponte 9, and between 6pm and 7pm, the “AAFK x Resonatorium Sound & Paint” will take place at Ponte e Horta square. Tomorrow, between 4pm and 5pm, it is time for the “Three Lamps of Inclusion: Culture Experience and Dialogue Workshop”, at Largo de Santo Agostinho, followed by the event “The City Breathes”, at Largo do Lilau. At night, between 8:30 pm and 9:20 pm, it is time for music and meditation with a performance by NÁV, in Largo de Santo Agostinho. On Sunday, a “placemaking” activity takes place between 11am and 12pm at Largo do Aquino, entitled “Love Me? Destroy Me!”, followed by a collective reading around the installation “Letters to Macau” between 4pm and 5pm, at Travessa do Aterro Novo. The biennial ends with the activity, between 6pm and 6:30pm, entitled “Furniture Adoption”, at Largo do Aquino. The program also includes several guided tours.

item.title: Universities of Macau and Timor-Leste agree to exchange students and teachers
item.description: The Macau Polytechnic University (UPM) announced on Friday an agreement with the National University of Timor-Leste (UNTL) for the exchange of students and teachers. In a statement, UPM indicated that the cooperation protocol also provides for the strengthening of ties in the area of ​​sharing academic resources and the training of qualified staff bilingual in Chinese and Portuguese. Both jurisdictions have Portuguese as one of their official languages, along with Chinese, in the case of the semi-autonomous region of Macau, and with Tetum, in the case of East Timor. The agreement was signed by the vice-rector of UPM, Vivian Lei Ngan Lin, and the rector of UNTL, João Soares Martins, on the sidelines of the 15th conference of the Forum for Higher Education Management in Portuguese-Speaking Countries and Regions (Forges). The annual meeting of Portuguese-speaking universities and polytechnics took place in the capital of Timor-Leste, Díli, in a joint organization of UNTL, the Timorese Catholic University São João Paulo II and the University of Díli. The Forges conference, which had as its theme “The Promotion of Scientific Research in the Portuguese Language in the Face of Global Challenges”, took place between the 24th and 27th of November. During the event, the deputy director of the Faculty of Languages ​​and Translation at UPM, the Portuguese Joaquim Carvalho, gave a presentation in which he invited students and teachers from Portuguese-speaking countries to invest in exchanges with Macau. International Network The UPM delegation also took advantage of the opportunity to discuss academic exchange and cooperation projects with the Portuguese Catholic University, the Pontifical Catholic University of Campinas (Brazil) and the University of Luanda. In November 2024, during the 14th Forges conference, in Macau, João Soares Martins told Lusa that UNTL wanted the support of the Instituto Português do Oriente (IPOR) to start certifying proficiency in the Portuguese language. Also in the Chinese region, UNTL and the University of Macau (UM) signed a cooperation agreement on Monday that provides “more opportunities for the mobility of teachers and students”, highlighted the rector. The Timorese delegation visited the Department of Portuguese at UM, the State Reference Laboratory for Quality Research in Chinese Medicine and the Faculty of Law, where some of the current UNTL teachers were trained. “It would be good for the University of Macau to be able to provide some vacancies for our teachers to continue their courses, both in master's and doctorate degrees”, highlighted Soares Martins.

item.title: ONE | Construction of the new campus has started
item.description: The construction start ceremony was attended by Sam Hou Fai. The new campus will include UM's first medical school Construction of the new campus of the University of Macau (UM), which will include the first public medical faculty, in collaboration with the University of Lisbon (ULisboa) began on Friday. In a statement, UM indicated that the laying of the first stone ceremony, presided over by Government leader, Sam Hou Fai, took place in the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone, in neighboring Hengqin (Mountain Island). The new campus will occupy an area of ​​almost 376,000 square meters in the special economic zone and construction is expected to take around three years, with a partial inauguration scheduled for 2028 and completion of works in 2029. Four new faculties will be created in the new UM campus on Ilha da Montanha, including those of Information Sciences, Design and Engineering, as well as the first public medical faculty in Macau. The University of Science and Technology of Macau, a private institution, has had a Faculty of Health Sciences since 2008, officially renamed the Faculty of Medicine in 2019. In June, the director of the Faculty of Medicine at Ulisboa told Lusa that doctors trained at the future Faculty of Medicine at UM will also be able to practice in Portugal. ULisboa is collaborating with UM to create a curriculum with a layout “close to the structure” of courses at the Portuguese institution, said Luís Graça. The director explained that the courses will work in co-supervision, allowing doctors trained at UM to obtain “equivalence and recognition” by the ULisboa Faculty of Medicine. Doctors for Portugal Among the advantages will be “thus allowing doctors trained in the territory to also practice medicine in Portugal”, highlighted the researcher. In December, the vice-rector of UM, Rui Martins, said that the new campus will focus on "'dual degrees' [courses in co-tutelship] with foreign universities. Medicine is already with Lisbon and now we are defining it for the other faculties". The new campus on Ilha da Montanha should allow UM to increase from the current 15 thousand to a maximum of 25 thousand students, highlighted the vice-rector for Global Affairs, in an interview with the Portuguese-language channel of the local public television TDM. Luís Graça, a specialist in transplant immunology, also expressed enthusiasm about potential collaborations between the two universities in the area of ​​scientific research. “If we think in terms of science, strengthening the scientific potential of both institutions with close collaboration between them is something that will clearly benefit both sides of this partnership”, stated the director. Luís Graça said that the ULisboa Faculty of Medicine is organizing the first symposium to bring together researchers from the institution and UM, with a view to promoting joint research projects.

item.title: Takeaway | No labor regulation plans
item.description: Chan Un Tong, director of the Department of Labor Affairs (DSAL), said there are no plans on the table to regulate the courier profession, which is intended to deliver take-away meals. According to TDM Rádio Macau, the person in charge responded to a written question from deputy Ngan Iek Hang, explaining that the labor and legal protection of couriers depends on the link they have with the platform that provides the delivery service. If there is a signed contract, the current labor law applies, but if there is only a service provision contract, the conditions agreed between the parties apply. The deputy stated, in the interpellation, that the take-away delivery sector already represents 48.3 percent of catering establishments, therefore suggesting improvements at a labor level.

item.title: Prostitution | Considered rule relief
item.description: The Government will ask residents for their opinion on a possible reduction in restrictions on saunas and massages, the only places in the region where prostitution is tolerated. At a press conference held on Thursday, Executive Council spokesperson Wong Sio Chak announced that the public consultation will be launched in the first half of 2026. The Executive intends to review the administrative licensing regime for specific economic activities, which was approved in 1998. Wong Sio Chak, also secretary for Administration and Justice, gave the example of auctions, barbershops and beauty salons and said that “some of the sectors will no longer need licenses and registration”. The change could have “great significance for the optimization of the business environment and the economic development of Macau”, namely by “giving more convenience to companies”, defended the director. However, Wong admitted that, since the review “represents a major political change”, the leader of the Government, Sam Hou Fai, “decided to listen to more opinions from the public” so as to “not harm the lives of citizens”.

item.title: Justice | Jerónimo Santos at TSI and Ho Wai Neng confirmed at TUI
item.description: Despite the departure of Portuguese people from Macau's courts in recent years, the only Portuguese judge remaining in the territory was promoted to the Court of Second Instance The only Portuguese judge working in Macau, Jerónimo Alberto Gonçalves Santos, was appointed to the Court of Second Instance (TSI), while Ho Wai Neng was confirmed as judge of the Court of Final Instance (TUI). The decisions were communicated on Friday and the appointment order was published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. The promotion of Jerónimo Santos comes at a time when the continuity of Portuguese magistrates in Macau is being called into question by the Portuguese authorities. In October of this year, fellow Portuguese judge Rui Ribeiro brought forward the end of a service commission, which lasted until May of next year, due to the uncertainty regarding the renewal of the special license, to be in Macau, from the Superior Council of Judiciary (CSM). Also in October, the president of the Supreme Court of Justice (STJ), João Cura Mariano, who inherently also presides over the CSM, stated that the Portuguese justice system is having “some difficulty in contributing judges”, due to the lack of qualified and experienced human resources. “Just now we removed a judge who had been here for many years and we needed him”, highlighted João Cura Mariano, in October. In 2024, the CSM rejected the stay of Portuguese TJB judge Carlos Carvalho, who had been in Macau for 16 years and had been invited by the Independent Commission for the Nomination of Judges in the territory to continue for another two years. The council did not authorize the renewal of Carlos Carvalho's special license and promoted him to judge, with placement at the Court of Appeal. Despite the nuances, João Cura Mariano assured that he was willing to help Macau, “despite the difficulties that currently exist in Portugal in recruiting judges”. Ascent confirmation The moves announced on Friday confirm Ho Wai Neng's elevation to the Court of Final Appeal, where he had been serving since Sam Hou Fai announced his candidacy for Chief Executive in April last year. Furthermore, Choi Mou Pan was appointed for a period of three years as president of the TSI, a position previously held by Ho Wai Neng. Among the promotions to the TSI, the name of Lou Ieng Ha also stands out, the judge responsible in the first instance for some of the most publicized cases in recent years, such as the Public Works case, which resulted in the convictions of former directors Jaime Carion and Li Canfeng, and also the Suncity case, which led to the businessman of Macau's largest gambling promoter, Alvin Chao, in prison. In terms of appointments, Io Weng San and Rong Qi were promoted to presiding judges of the Collective Court of First Instance Courts. All appointments take effect next year, and nominations came from the Independent Commission for the Appointment of Judges. The committee is made up of Lau Cheok Va, president, Ho Teng Iat, Ieong Tou Hong, Chan Hong, Wang Yu, Song Man Lei and António José Dias Azedo. With Lusa

item.title: Budget | Public expenditure rises until November due to social support
item.description: Compared to last year, the Government spent 4.1 percent more on social expenses until November, which rose to 49.7 billion patacas. The increase in public spending was balanced with casino revenues Public expenditure increased by 2.7 percent in the first 11 months of 2025, compared to the same period last year, following a budget review to reinforce social support, it was announced on Friday. According to data published online by the Financial Services Directorate (DSF), the Macao SAR spent 86.1 billion patacas by the end of November. The main reason for the increase was spending on social support and subsidies, which grew 4.1 percent compared to the first 11 months of 2024, to 49.7 billion patacas. At the beginning of July, the Legislative Assembly approved a Government proposal to increase the expenses foreseen in the budget by 2.86 billion patacas, to reinforce social support. The review includes the creation of a subsidy, worth a total of MOP54,000, for children up to three years old, in an attempt to increase the lowest birth rate in the world. On the contrary, spending on public works, the Administration's Investment and Expense Plan, fell 2.7 percent until November, to 14.7 billion patacas. Tax revenue The increase in expenditure was balanced by Macau's current revenue, which rose 2.8 percent in the first 11 months of the year, to 104.6 billion patacas. The main reason for the increase was a 7 percent increase, to 86.7 billion patacas, in revenue from gambling taxes – which represent 81.3 percent of the total. The city's six gaming operators pay a direct tax of 35 percent on gaming revenue, with 2.4 percent going to the Macau Social Security Fund and urban and tourism development, and 1.6 percent given to the Macau Foundation for cultural, educational, scientific, academic and philanthropic purposes. Total revenue from Macau's casinos reached 226.5 billion patacas in the first 11 months of the year, 8.6 percent more than in the same period in 2024. The territory ended November with a surplus in public accounts of 20.6 billion patacas, 11.4 percent more than in the same period last year. Macau ended 2024 with a surplus of 15.8 billion patacas, more than double that recorded in the previous year. The Government's initial forecast for the entire year 2025 pointed to a surplus of 6.83 billion patacas. But the revised budget, approved by the Legislative Assembly at the beginning of July, predicted a surplus of just 191.1 million patacas.

item.title: Zone A | Ramp and pedestrian crossing will cost at least 54 million
item.description: An access ramp for road traffic to Zone A of the New Landfills and a pedestrian crossing will cost the public coffers between “more than 54 million patacas and more than 63 million patacas”, said the Public Works Services Department (DSOP) yesterday. The values ​​represent the cheapest and most expensive proposals presented by companies applying for the public tender for the “Construction Contract for the Extension of the A1 Access Road Ramp and a Pedestrian Crossing for Pedestrians”. The 17 proposals, all admitted, were announced yesterday. The work will have a construction period of 285 working days. The work seeks to improve connections between Zone A and the peninsula, through the “access ramp, in one direction, on the current A1 access road, to facilitate direct access for vehicles to Avenida da Ponte Macau, on the east side of Zone A, via Avenida da Ponte da Amizade and Avenida do Nordeste, and divert vehicles wishing to access the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge Border Post and those heading to Taipa via the Bridge Macao”. In addition, “an uneven pedestrian walkway will be built on the coast of the northern end of Zone A of the New Urban Landfills, which will connect the two east and west sides of Zone A”.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke long and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now.
