It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. Eu nem sempre conheço todos os premiados – desconhecia a existência da Louise Glück, que acho uma grande poeta, ou da Olga Tokarczuk, por exemplo – mas isso só me traz o conforto de saber que o mundo não é uma telenovela onde toda a gente se conhece e a alegria de reconhecer que a bitola do mundo não se mede com a minha medida curta e que pelo contrário dá-me uma nova oportunidade para enfrentar o desconhecido e aprender com ele. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technology and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the place of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will indeed be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Hong Kong | Main opposition party dissolved
item.description: The Hong Kong Democratic Party yesterday approved its own dissolution, under pressure from the territory's security laws, which prevent it from carrying out its activities. In a two-hour meeting, 97 percent of members voted to disband the party, once one of the biggest forces in Hong Kong's Legislative Council. At the annual assembly, according to the South China Morning Post, a total of 117 members, 97 percent of those present, agreed to the party's dissolution, following the decision taken by the party leadership in February. Veteran member and former deputy Fred Li Wah-ming said a mainland Chinese official had urged the party to dissolve before December's Legislative Council elections. This dissolution of the party eliminates what little remains of the city's main political opposition, following a similar decision by the League of Social Democrats in June and the closure of the Civic Party in 2023. The Hong Kong Association for Democracy and People's Welfare, which focuses on social issues and advocates for residents to vote under the revamped electoral system, is the only remaining pro-democracy force. The patriots Currently, with the various arrests of leaders and activists and the limitations on candidacies, the democratic party did not have any representation in the legislative council or district councils. The issue became even more complex in March 2021, when the Chinese government passed a law designed to ensure that only those it designated as 'patriots' could govern in Hong Kong. This regulation significantly reduced democratic representation in the assembly, consolidated control over electoral processes and established a candidate selection panel aligned with Beijing's interests. Since this legislation and electoral reforms came into force, the future of the Democratic Party has been at risk, following constant police raids and arrests of activists or family members in recent years. A few months ago, party members authorized the sale of their headquarters for 11 million Hong Kong dollars to prepare for eventual dissolution and prevent the property from being handed over to the courts. The party's remaining funds are to be donated to the Association for the Rights of Victims of Industrial Accidents.

item.title: Fighting between Thailand and Cambodia continues
item.description: Thailand and Cambodia continue fighting along the border, as the conflict enters its second week, after Bangkok denied that it had said “yes” to a ceasefire, announced by the President of the United States, Donald Trump. The hostilities, which broke out on December 7, have so far caused at least 33 deaths and more than 200 injuries, in addition to around 800,000 people being displaced on both sides of the border. The two countries accuse each other of having unleashed hostilities and attacking civilians. Last Friday, Donald Trump stated that the leaders of the two countries had agreed to a ceasefire after a phone call from him, but the Thai Government denied this commitment and the fighting continued this Saturday and continued yesterday. According to Thai Defense Ministry spokesman Surasant Kongsiri, Cambodia shelled several border provinces on Saturday night and yesterday. The Cambodian counterpart, Maly Socheata, accused Thai forces of continuing to bomb and fire mortars in areas close to the border since midnight on Sunday. Cambodia closed its land borders with Thailand this Saturday, leaving thousands of people stranded on both sides of the border. The decision, according to Phnom Penh, aims to protect civilians — including foreigners of various nationalities, who were unable to cross the border into Thailand — from the risks associated with military clashes, which last week included the use of fighter jets and artillery fire along the border, which is around 820 kilometers long. Cambodia has asked its citizens living in Thailand and Thais hoping to return to their country to remain where they are “until the ceasefire is fully enforced.” Thailand, in turn, expressed concern about this decision by Phnom Penh, especially as it expected the return on Saturday of around 7,000 Thais who had been waiting for days at the border to enter the country and who are now prohibited from crossing it by land. "These actions violate numerous provisions of international law that, for our part, Thailand respects. I guarantee that Cambodians and other foreign citizens living in Thailand will receive assistance in accordance with international law", said deputy spokesperson for the Thai Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Maratee Nalita Andamo, at a press conference yesterday. An old case Thailand and Cambodia dispute the sovereignty of territories where Khmer Empire temples are located along a border of around 820 kilometers, drawn at the beginning of the 20th century during the French colonial period. In July this year, a first episode of violence caused 43 deaths in five days and forced around 300,000 people to leave their homes in areas close to the common border, before a ceasefire under the auspices of the United States, China and Malaysia. The two countries then signed a ceasefire agreement on October 26, under the aegis of Donald Trump, which Bangkok suspended a few weeks later, following the explosion of a mine that injured several of its soldiers, and which Thailand accuses of having been installed after the ceasefire.

item.title: Diplomacy | China and India highlight “positive advances” in bilateral relations
item.description: Senior diplomatic officials from China and India highlighted “recent positive progress” in the bilateral relationship in Beijing on Thursday, during a new round of consultations between the two countries' foreign ministries. According to a statement released Friday by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the meeting was led by Liu Jinsong, director-general of the Asia Department, and by Shri Sujit Ghosh, joint secretary of the Indian ministry for East Asia, and took place in a “timely and efficient” manner. During the talks, both parties defended the need to relaunch institutional dialogue mechanisms, boost bilateral exchanges and adequately manage divergences and sensitive issues. The delegations also reiterated their commitment to strengthening communication and coordination in multilateral forums, promoting multilateralism and supporting the construction of a multipolar international order. The consultations take place in a context of rapprochement between Beijing and New Delhi, after years of tension, and following measures such as the resumption of border trade, the reopening of direct air links and the relaunch of high-level diplomatic contacts. Despite the positive signs, the relationship remains marked by fundamental differences, especially around the common border in the Himalayas, where a deadly clash in 2020 provoked the worst bilateral crisis in decades. According to the Chinese statement, the delegations agreed to “maximize the positive aspects” of the Sino-Indian relationship.

item.title: Tai Po | Commission announced to investigate fire
item.description: The working group, led by judge David Lok, hopes to present results on the reasons behind the tragedy, which left at least 160 people dead, within nine months Hong Kong authorities announced Friday the investigation committee that will be responsible for analyzing the circumstances of the November 26 fire at the Wang Fuk Court residential complex, which caused at least 160 deaths. The commission will be led by the judge of the Court of First Instance of the High Court of Hong Kong, David Lok, “and will formally begin work at the end of this month, with the prospect of completing the work nine months after the start of the task”, according to a statement published by the executive of the Chinese special administrative region. The commission will examine all aspects of the fire, starting with the causes that accelerated the spread of the flames, supposedly attributed to the protective materials used in the building's repairs, but will also assess the firefighters' response to the distress call and the legal status of the works. According to the team's final conclusions, the commission will present to the territory's Chief Executive, John Lee, a series of proposals to prepare. The president promised the population a series of “profound reforms, with the aim of preventing similar incidents from happening again”. During the commission's announcement, John Lee admitted that the investigating judge faces a “titanic task” and that perhaps nine months is an insufficient period of time. “The fact is that I want to resolve this issue as quickly as possible and I decided to set a deadline that I consider realistic, as long as the commission has sufficient means to act,” he stated. "It's a huge responsibility and a challenge in just nine months, but they all have the passion and love for Hong Kong needed to take on this responsibility with such courage. I am deeply grateful to them," he concluded. Managers concerned Anti-corruption authorities are directly investigating 13 people linked to the fire under the presumption of having committed negligent homicide, including the directors and an engineering consultant of a construction company responsible for the building's renovation work. On Tuesday, the United Nations expressed concern over the arrests of people demanding explanations about the worst fire the city has suffered in decades. “Hong Kongers rightfully demand answers and that those responsible be held accountable, so that the hundreds of victims are duly compensated and so that a tragedy like this does not happen again,” said United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Turk, in a statement. Following the fire on November 26, authorities issued a warning against those who “exploit the tragedy”, having so far arrested four people for sedition.

item.title: Diplomacy | Alerta para perigos de rearmamento nipónico
item.description: The new Japanese Prime Minister's provocative statements about Taiwan, combined with the change in Japanese attitudes towards Defense, raised alarm bells in the Middle East country. A spokesperson for China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday that China calls on all peace-loving countries to protect themselves and thwart any dangerous moves to revive Japanese militarism and jointly defend the hard-won victorious results of the Second World War, according to the People's Daily. Spokesperson Guo Jiakun made the remarks at a press conference in response to a question about recent comments by some foreign media that Japan is transforming from a constitutionally pacifist state into a modern military power, and that the country is trying to revive militarism, which could threaten regional and global peace and stability and deserves vigilance. Guo noted that in recent years, Japan has been reformulating its security and defense policies, accelerating the revision of its pacifist constitution and violating the exclusively defense-oriented principle. Furthermore, the country removed the ban on the exercise of the right to collective self-defense, relaxed restrictions on arms exports, attempted to change its three non-nuclear principles and developed the so-called “capability to attack enemy bases”. The official highlighted that senior Japanese officials even declared that Japan does not rule out the possibility of possessing nuclear submarines. “These measures have placed Japan’s neighboring countries and the international community on alert,” Guo said. "We note that after increasing its defense budget in 13 consecutive years, Japan now has the second largest military budget among Western countries. According to a European think tank, the revenues of Japan's five largest defense companies will increase by 40 percent annually in 2024," Guo pointed out. “For a country that calls itself constitutionally pacifist, talks about reflecting on its military past and claims to follow the principle exclusively oriented towards defense, how does Japan justify its military increase?”, asked Guo. Distorted looks The MNE representative went on to say that, in fact, after World War II, the Japanese government never fully reflected on its wars of aggression, many Japanese war criminals returned as active political figures and members of the Self-Defense Forces, some prime ministers and political dignitaries have insisted on visiting and paying homage to the Yasukuni Shrine, where Class A war criminals are honored. Historical facts have been minimized and covered up in distorted textbooks, Guo added. "Japanese right-wing forces reflected on the war's past. However, they did not reflect on Japan's war crimes, but on the reason why Japan was defeated," Guo noted. The MNE spokesperson stated that the reckoning with Japanese militarism was never completed. Instead, people will see a growing trend toward the resurgence of militarism. It is imperative for the international community to remind Japan that the Potsdam Declaration, in articles 6, 7, 9 and 11, stated that Japanese militarism and its breeding ground must be eliminated forever, as we insist that a new order of peace, security and justice will be impossible until there is convincing evidence that Japan's power to wage war has been destroyed politically and legally and that bellicose ideas have been fundamentally eliminated, Guo said. The representative further highlighted that the Potsdam Proclamation also requires that Japan be completely disarmed and not maintain industries that would allow it to rearm for war, and that it is promised in Japan's Instrument of Surrender that the country will faithfully comply with the provisions of the Potsdam Proclamation. These instruments with legal effect under international law and recognized by Japan have clarified its international obligations as a defeated country, constitute an important cornerstone of the post-war international order, and serve as a political and legal prerequisite for Japan's return to the international community, the spokesperson noted. "Japan's attempt to 'remilitarize' itself through the accelerated strengthening of its armed forces will only make the world question where Japan is heading and demand another reckoning with its war crimes. China calls on all peace-loving countries to protect themselves and thwart any dangerous moves to revive Japanese militarism and to jointly defend the hard-won victorious results of the Second World War," said Guo.

item.title: Timor-Leste and Brazil sign agreement to train Portuguese teachers
item.description: The Timorese Government and Brazil signed on Wednesday a training project for Portuguese language teachers in Timor-Leste, to reinforce teachers' linguistic, communicative and didactic-pedagogical skills. “The Portuguese Language Teacher Training Project for the 3rd Cycle of Basic Education, which we formalized today through the signing of a complementary agreement and a project document, is born from a profound commitment: to ensure that all our teachers have the linguistic, communicative, didactic-pedagogical and methodological skills necessary to ensure the successful implementation of the new national curriculum, which came into force in the academic year 2025”, he stated Sweet Jesus. The Timorese Minister of Education was speaking during the signing ceremony of the training program, which will last four years (2025 to 2028). The project will cover a total of 644 Portuguese language teachers from the 3rd Cycle of Basic Education, directly involved in the teaching and learning process of young Timorese. “To improve this process, we will have the technical support of 17 Brazilian teacher-coordinators, who will work under a joint teaching regime, and 81 Timorese teachers, who will act as multiplier teachers, thus guaranteeing the sustainability and continuity of training in the future”, explained the Timorese minister. The project also includes the production of new teaching materials for the 7th, 8th and 9th years, the creation of a Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) and the establishment, at the National Institute for the Training of Teachers and Education Professionals (INFORDEPE), of a Portuguese Teacher Training Center, which will function as a permanent technical and pedagogical support structure. "We all understand that this is a strategic and ambitious investment. An investment that goes beyond simply training teachers and that represents the construction of a sustainable model for the future of training and education in Timor-Leste", added Dulce de Jesus. Expanding The Brazilian ambassador to Timor-Leste, Ricardo José Leal, stated that the Brazilian Government is committed to continuing to collaborate with Timor-Leste, especially in the promotion and dissemination of the Portuguese language. “Teacher training aims to train teachers and expand the use of the Portuguese language, especially in basic education”, declared the Brazilian diplomat. The project has support from the Brazilian Government through the Brazilian Cooperation Agency (ABC) and the University of Campinas (UNICAMP), which have provided consistent technical and scientific support to improve the educational system in Timor-Leste.

item.title: IMF | Highly revised China growth to 5% by 2025
item.description: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) yesterday revised upwards the growth forecast for the Chinese economy for 2025, from 4.8 percent to 5 percent, citing the economic stimuli launched by Beijing and the trade truce with the United States. The update is contained in the annual assessment of the Chinese economy, released yesterday, which also raises the growth projection for 2026, from 4.2 percent to 4.5 percent. The IMF mission, led by Sonali Jain-Chandra, highlighted the “remarkable resilience” of the Chinese economy despite “multiple disruptions in recent years”. Still, he warned of persistent imbalances, such as the prolonged adjustment of the real estate sector, the impact on local finances and weak consumer confidence, which resulted in low domestic demand and deflationary pressures. For 2025, the IMF forecasts average inflation of 0 percent, with a moderate recovery to 0.8 percent next year. The mission also warned of medium-term risks, such as the aging of the population, the slowdown in productivity and high levels of debt. Despite the external competitiveness benefited by the real devaluation of the yuan, the IMF considers that exports can no longer sustain growth alone. The IMF recommends a faster transition to a consumption-based growth model, by reducing the high rate of household savings, greater exchange rate flexibility, strengthening social protection systems and responding to the housing crisis. Reforms in the labor market to reduce youth unemployment and restructuring local government debt through insolvency mechanisms are other proposals put forward.

item.title: East Timor | Agreements with Asian Development Bank canceled
item.description: The Timorese Government decided yesterday to cancel three financing agreements with the Asian Development Bank, including the one relating to the Nicolau Lobato airport expansion project, signed in 2021. The Timorese executive justified the decision “following an in-depth analysis of the various projects financed by loans, which again highlighted the existence of initiatives that have yet to start or with very low levels of execution”, can be read in the statement from the Council of Ministers. In addition to the financing agreement for the expansion of the airport, worth US$85 million, the Government also decided to cancel financing for the “Power Distribution Modernization” projects, signed in December 2021, worth US$35 million, and for “Dili West Water Supply”, signed in 2022, worth US$50 million. In this context, certain financing agreements currently in force are no longer necessary”, highlighted the Timorese Government. At the meeting, the Government also approved the signing of a loan agreement, with a subsidy component, with the Asian Development Bank to finance the “Improvement of National Roads” project, phase 1. “This project aims to modernize around 42 kilometers of important roads in the national road network, introducing small-scale climate adaptation infrastructure in six juices [groups of villages] prone to floods and droughts”, explained the Government. The project also includes the rehabilitation of three bridges located between Baucau and Lautém, in the east of the country.

item.title: Seoul | Protest after incursion of military planes from Beijing and Moscow
item.description: Seoul announced yesterday that it had lodged a “strong diplomatic protest” with Russian and Chinese authorities after military planes from Beijing and Moscow passed through the South Korean air defense identification zone. The protest was lodged with the defense attachés of both countries in the South Korean capital, according to the Ministry of Defense. “Our armed forces will continue to actively respond to the activities of aircraft from neighboring countries within [the South Korean air defense identification zone], in accordance with international law”, highlighted the head of international affairs at that ministry, Lee Kwang-suk. South Korea said on Tuesday it sent fighter jets in response to the entry of seven Russian and two Chinese military aircraft into the country's air defense zone. This zone is an area larger than airspace that a country controls for security reasons, although this concept is not defined by any international treaty. None of the Russian and Chinese military aircraft violated South Korean airspace, according to the Joint Chiefs of Staff in Seoul. Beijing and Moscow evoked joint military exercises that, according to the Russian Ministry of Defense, involved “strategic bombers”.

item.title: Luís Bernardino, académico: “Precisamos definir uma estratégia de cooperação-defesa” para a CPLP
item.description: The book “25 Years of Defense Cooperation at CPLP” was released in 2023 in digital format and, two years later, reached the printed version. Luís Bernardino, co-author linked to the Autonomous University of Lisbon, highlights positive developments since the creation of the Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, despite inaction and controversies with Equatorial Guinea “25 Years of Defense Cooperation in the CPLP [Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries]” was released as an e-book and is now available in print. Why edit this book? This book talks about the 25 years of cooperation in the CPLP defense area and is written by me, together with a colleague from Brazil, Camila Rizzi. It results from a research project developed at the CPLP Strategic Analysis Center, based in Mozambique. It has the CPLP defense component and makes strategic reflection on this topic. Due to the fact that 25 years of cooperation have passed in this area, we wanted to carry out an evaluation and the book so that it would remain in the history of the organization. In 2023, there were no financial conditions to publish the book on paper as we wanted, and it was now launched on November 18th, in Maputo. There is criticism regarding the effective action of the CPLP. Do you consider that this organism has grown sustainably? The assessment I make is in the area of ​​defense. When the CPLP was created, cooperation in the area of ​​defense was not included in the initial six areas. This area only emerged in 1998. The CPLP was born with six main areas – culture, language, political-diplomatic concentration – and currently has 26 areas of cooperation, which is proof that it has grown in a sustained manner. Obviously, with ups and downs, situations have become easier over these almost 30 years. But what stands out in this book, in the area of ​​defense, is that there was a very consolidated and participated growth. In these 25 years, a lot of interesting things have been done and the evaluation is positive. And the future? We need to define a defense cooperation strategy and what we want for the CPLP in this area over the next 25 years. This is the challenge we face, of greater activity and initiative, so that cooperation and defense can be strategic in what is cooperation within States. So that it can be more visible and effectively allow for growth, participation and development, or even greater commitment, in regional contexts. But looking at the past, present and future, what has the dynamic been like in the defense area? The book shows a certain dynamic of substantial constitutional growth in the first phase. Then there were very interesting developments, with some protocols and cooperation at the level of the Armed Forces, but there is still a lot to do, namely looking at the area of ​​defense cooperation as a strategic area. The global geopolitical system appears to be changing very quickly, following a multipolar path. Should the CPLP have another role in this context, with actors such as China, Russia or the United States? The CPLP is not a multilateral instrument, it is not an organization of that level. We have to place the CPLP at the level of the Commonwealth, for example, of organizations at a cultural, linguistic level, of partnership between countries, of concern for development. What I usually say is that the CPLP is a good diplomatic communication instrument, a soft power in areas related to conflict management and prevention. Let us not expect there to be armed forces, or an army, from the CPLP. This body is one of dialogue and cooperation. What we do, in terms of defense, is exactly that, create partnerships so that there are mechanisms for responding to disasters, to provide training capacity for the armed forces. There are even those who ask the question: why did the CPLP not intervene in Cabo Delgado, in Mozambique, on the issue of terrorism? And why? Because the CPLP is not a hard power mechanism, it has no capacity, doctrine, logistics, mandate or viability to be used in combat operations. And CPLP Member States are very aware that we are a very good mechanism for cooperation, partnership and development, with contributions to culture and language. Therefore, the CPLP will not intervene in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, because that is not its area, nor does it have mechanisms for this dynamic. Is the existence of the CPLP justified? I think so, obviously, because, as I said, the CPLP is a very good instrument in terms of cooperation, the dissemination of the Portuguese language, of history. The fact is that we have around 350 million people who speak Portuguese. We have 30 countries that are associated observers, such as Ukraine, Chile, and Portuguese culture is represented in this organization. Each country has what it wants from the CPLP and gives it the importance it thinks it should give, and this depends on the foreign policy of each State. But I think the CPLP makes a lot of sense in the world we live in, and does so as a multilateral representative of language, culture, cooperation between Portuguese-speaking states, and those that ultimately have some affinity [with the Portuguese-speaking world]. The Macau issue is very specific to this organization. Macau has the role of a commercial platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries, and China has an agenda for Lusophony. Before 1999 Macau had its own status within the CPLP, as it was administered by Portuguese. There was a Joint Declaration that allowed Macau, not being a Member State, to have, in a certain way, a protocol [with the CPLP]. When it became a Macao SAR, things changed and it lost that connection status, and Macau is not a member of the CPLP, and obviously cannot be. Neither does China, and it cannot be. Therefore, there is an associated observer status here that arises for countries, international and regional organizations, and even territorial entities with their own administration, which is also not quite the case in Macau. The territory is in limbo, between having a very strong history linked to Lusofonia, and having an administration very linked to China, which gives it, in my perspective, two dynamics. In what sense? Macau is a fundamental element in the connection between the CPLP countries and China. For all reasons, but due to the issue of language, history, and its representation, it is a fundamental actor in this cooperation. Macau must effectively be seen as a partner and as a gateway for China to Portuguese-speaking countries. This is what, in a way, is already happening, and this is what the CPLP will be paying attention to, in this relationship in which Macau has a special status. Whether we like it or not, it has an impact. Macau is an attractive factor in facilitating relations between China and Angola, Portugal or Brazil. Does Equatorial Guinea's stay in the CPLP raise questions of credibility? I agree with you. In these 30 years, it has been one of the main difficult moments in creating consensus. I remember that Equatorial Guinea was admitted in 2014, but there was already a process in the previous analysis phase. There was always an extension, year after year, and it was difficult to reach a consensus within the CPLP countries. In 2014, there was a summit in Timor-Leste and, through the action of Brazil and Angola, there was, in a way, a lot of pressure for Equatorial Guinea to join. But there are two principles, for better and for worse, that justify Equatorial Guinea's presence in the CPLP. What are… The first argument is that, in fact, Equatorial Guinea has Portuguese as its official language in its Constitution, despite us knowing that the Portuguese language, for example, covers four or five percent of society as a whole, and I am already being quite generous. But there is a commitment from the Equatorial Guinea authorities to develop Portuguese as a working language and there is a historical connection to Portuguese culture and Lusophony. Another criterion is the promise that, in the next constitutional review, a commitment will be made to abolish the death penalty. As for Portuguese, it's something that takes generations, it's not done from one year to the next. Not even in the next 10 or 15 years will we have Portuguese perfectly implemented. There is some shyness, a commitment, in a way. As for the death penalty, the fact is that, it seems, some change has been achieved. There has never been a death penalty action again [since accession]. And there is hope that, in the next constitutional review, this fact will be abolished from the Constitution and that it may, effectively, cease to exist. As a member of the CPLP, these changes will be easier and more visible and, in the future, Equatorial Guinea can effectively assume CPLP status taking these premises into account. I don't know if it will happen, I leave here a reluctance, and this is a challenging moment for the CPLP itself. Work needs to be done from within, so that Equatorial Guinea can be at the same level as other countries, especially in these two areas. What is certain is that there remains a certain lack of transparency regarding what is happening in the country. We are aware that Equatorial Guinea has major problems with issues of democratic legitimacy and elections. There are a series of situations that we recognize are not perfectly adequate given the status of CPLP countries. I think there is hope that things can change, an attempt to create space for Portuguese to grow within Equatorial Guinea, and also a commitment to greater openness and participation. What is a fact is that Equatorial Guinea has participated in CPLP meetings, and I have participated in some. In international situations we have to be pragmatic, and we hope that, just because Equatorial Guinea is in the CPLP, this can help Guinea itself to develop some mechanical gestures.

item.title: Timor-Leste / Independence – Mari Alkatiri: Proclamation was anticipated by the Indonesian military presence
item.description: Interview by Isabel Marisa Serafim, from the Lusa agency The leader of the Revolutionary Front of Independent Timor-Leste (Fretilin), Mari Alkatiri, said that the unilateral proclamation of independence was scheduled for December 1, 1975, but was brought forward because Indonesian troops were already in the territory. “It was initially scheduled for December 1st,” said Mari Alkatiri, in an interview with Lusa on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence, which is marked on Friday, and of the Indonesian occupation, nine days later, on December 7th. In November, Mari Alkatiri went on a “safari” through several African countries, mainly the Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP), which involved participating in the declaration of Angola’s independence on November 11, 1975. "After this 'tour', this African 'safari', I returned to the country. At the time I was in Maputo to prepare my return and I received a call from Nicolau Lobato not to return, because we needed to have someone outside the country", he recalled, highlighting that he did not follow the order from the then vice-president of Fretilin. “So I returned to Dili on the 22nd or 23rd of November and the central committee and military political committee were meeting at the current headquarters of the National Police of Timor-Leste, which was the provisional headquarters of Fretilin, and the proclamation for December 1st was being discussed”, he explained. On November 28, Mari Alkatiri, then 25 years old, recalled that Nicolau Lobato came to her house and said that it was necessary to proclaim independence that day. "We both left in his car for Lahane where Xavier do Amaral [former president of Fretilin] was and we conveyed this to Xavier Amaral, who clearly said to wait another three or four days. We said there was no time to wait and we decided to make the proclamation that day in the afternoon", he said. "Fortunately, not only was the Constitution ready, but also the flag was ready. It was my mother who sewed the flag. There were minimum conditions for the proclamation of independence", stated the current secretary general of Fretilin, who also wrote the text of the proclamation. “When I start talking about these days it’s not just memory, I actively participated in the unilateral proclamation of independence, although people try to cut out my photo, politics, but the truth is that there is only one person still alive who actively participated in the proclamation 50 years ago, that’s me”, he highlighted. In the first Timorese Government, led by Nicolau Lobato and which only lasted nine days, Mari Alkatiri was appointed Minister of State for Political Affairs. Nocolau Lobato led the fight against the Indonesian occupation and was assassinated in December 1978. The restoration of independence took place on May 20, 2002, after a referendum for self-determination on August 30, 1999 and 24 years of resistance against Indonesia. A question of egos Mari Alkatiri also stated, in the same interview, that “egos” are preventing Timor-Leste from overcoming the challenges and that a more democratic, inclusive and comprehensive leadership culture is needed. "If we managed it at the time, with all the difficulties, with all the challenges to overcome, at almost the speed of light, why can't we today? That's the question, the question of the cause. When the cause unites, the journey can go on, with many setbacks here and there, but we will succeed and we will win", said Mari Alkatiri in an interview with Lusa on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence, which marks this Friday. Asked about the reason for no union, the leader of the Revolutionary Front of Independent Timor-Leste (Fretilin) ​​said it was “egos”. “I am following the budget debate, when we continue to think about State matters in a 'cantin' way, we are not going anywhere”, criticized the former East Timorese Prime Minister, whose party chose to abstain in the final global vote on the State Budget. Regarding criticism of the current government's options, Mari Alkatiri said she did not know if there was ever an option. "I don't see a strategy. There are some successes here and there, tries here and there, but there is no strategy, but there is a lot of support for strategic planning, strategic investment, but I don't see it", he stated. “There is a need for a much more democratic, much more inclusive, very comprehensive leadership culture, with a sense of mission and vision for the future”, highlighted the secretary general of Fretilin. The party leader also warned not to wait for the “bomb to explode”. “The delay bomb is there, the time bomb is there, I hope we don’t have to, after that, apologize for the truth, after the bomb goes off”, he highlighted. Asked if the “bomb” is dissatisfaction, the former prime minister said: “complete”. "A country that after 24 years of restoring independence, with the means it had to work, why did it fail? Lack of sense of inclusion. We are building a State, we talk about the Democratic Rule of Law, is that true? Or oligarchic", he asked. The new generations Still in relation to young people, who represent the majority of the approximately 1.4 million inhabitants of Timor-Leste, Mari Alkatiri said that they feel lost. "Young people are naturally more generous when they are more considered, or more rebellious, when they are revolted. There are two facets here in youth, one of generosity when they embrace a cause, the other is a much more violent reaction of confrontation", he said. Pointing out that more than 70% of the population is under 35 years old, Mari Alkatiri warned that those “two generations have already been sacrificed” due to “poor quality” education and “increasingly worse health” and “no prospects”. “Now, we all say that oil money will run out, I see that for the Government, the alternative to oil is oil”, he said. In September, the capital of the Timor-Leste Petroleum Fund was US$18.95 billion (€16.4 billion). “We kept dreaming about Sunrise and as I usually say while we dream about Sunrise, we will have the ‘sunset’, because there is no politics, there are no plans, there are no programs”, he added. Mari Alkatiri was referring to the Greater Sunrise gas field, located 150 kilometers from Timor-Leste and 450 kilometers from Darwin, whose project has been mired in an impasse, with Dili defending the construction of a gas pipeline to the south of the country, and Woodside, the consortium's second largest partner, leaning towards a connection to the existing unit in Darwin. The consortium is made up of the Timorese company Timor Gap (56.56%), the operator Woodside Energy (33.44%) and Osaca Gás (10.00%). The Government of Timor-Leste announced on Saturday the signing of a cooperation agreement with the Australian Woodside Energy for studies to process and export gas to the country. Missing discussions The secretary general of the Revolutionary Front of Independent Timor-Leste (Fretilin), Mari Alkatiri, defended the need for “all together” to discuss what failed in the last 24 years, after the restoration of independence in May 2002. "There is a lot of talk about new paradigms and the old paradigm, we are ready to sit down together to discuss the old paradigm, why did it fail? No", said the former Timorese prime minister, in an interview with Lusa on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence, which marks this Friday. For Mari Alkatiri, everyone contributed with “their positive part, with their negative part”, but it is necessary to understand the failures in “individual terms”, in “collective terms” and there be “responsibility”. Asked by Lusa about the reasons why there is no such discussion, the leader of the Timorese opposition replied that a “leader who cannot sit at the table is not a leader”. "The leader must know that there is a time to sit at the table. I made proposals. When I returned in 2018, I said 'my vote is so that the people can win', I didn't say for Fretilin to win. The message was clear, it was time for us all to think together. I ran the campaign saying Fretilin wins, Xanana wins", stated Mari Alkatiri. The Fretilin leader said the response has been “revenge, hate”. "In such a way that to take revenge on me, it affects hundreds of people, families. If it's me, come and talk to me, you don't have to harm others, but this is a specific issue", he stated, referring to the Timorese Prime Minister, XAnana Gusmão. The fundamental issue, continued Maria Alkatiri, is “to have a sense of mission, a vision of the future and to have a common cause”. "What is crucial is knowing all the money that was spent, what was done. A balance of collective and individual performance. When we were waging war, we knew what we wanted, to restore independence, 24 years after the restoration of independence we don't know where we are going", lamented the leader. Mari Alkatiri also said he was “very concerned” about the report by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), which warned on September 11 of the proliferation of criminal networks in Oecussi, a Timorese enclave on the Indonesian side of the island of Timor, highlighting that recent investigations show contamination of the region. "It is already being absorbed by the mafia cartel, who are coming here in all their strength. We have closed kiosks and we think we are fighting the mafia. I am very worried," he said. For the future, Mari Alkatiri stated that he will continue to fight, but to “create critical mass”. "My fight now is not the concern with electoral cycles, but how I can actually create a true critical mass in Timor-Leste. Let's end blindness, many of our academic intellectuals get pregnant through their ears, but they don't get pregnant", he highlighted. The Fretilin leader also told everyone in his generation that it is time to put “egos” aside and start “thinking together”, highlighting that they have another five years to do so. “The next term of governance must be the product of understanding if we really want this country to move forward”, stated Mari Alkatiri, highlighting that the Timorese people deserve “much more and much better” than what has been given to date.

item.title: Independence | Ramos-Horta: It is “thanks to Xanana” that Timor-Leste is here
item.description: The Timorese President, José Ramos-Horta, highlighted, in an interview with Lusa, the journey of the current prime minister and former leader of the residence, highlighting that it is “thanks to Xanana [Gusmão]” that Timor-Leste is here today. “Xanana survived and with an impressive willpower, which few human beings can have, reorganizes the resistance, new attacks against the Indonesians”, said Ramos-Horta, in an interview with Lusa on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the declaration of independence, on November 28, 1975, remembering the attacks that the prime minister was the target of. The Timorese leader lost men and suffered setbacks, but organized the clandestine network and resistance in the occupied cities. Xanana Gusmão was elected leader of the resistance and commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces for the National Liberation of Timor-Leste (FALINTL) in 1981, having launched the National Unity Policy, developed the Clandestine Front and established the National Council of Maubere Resistance, later named the National Council of Timorese Resistance. "We reached the referendum in 1999 thanks to Xanana, not thanks to anyone else, obviously, the church got involved, because Xanana had the lucidity to talk to D. Martinho da Costa Lopes, abandon Marxism-Leninism. Thanks to Xanana that we are here today", stated the head of state. Martinho da Costa Lopes was one of the most important figures in the Catholic Church in East Timor during the Indonesian occupation and played a central role in defending the human rights of the Timorese. José Ramos-Horta also regretted that they now say that Xanana Gusmão is no longer the great man he was during the fight. "I say: gentlemen, now he was also the one who won the maritime border for us. I don't know who would win", he said, referring to the negotiation of maritime borders with Australia, concluded in 2018 and led by the current prime minister. The President also highlighted that Xanana Gusmão was the one who took the historic decision to diversify from the Petroleum Fund in 2009, which “brought 11 billion dollars in return to Timor” and carried out the reconciliation, without persecution or judgment from anyone. José Ramos-Horta also highlighted that it is Xanana Gusmão who “continues to have the technical competence” to discuss maritime borders with Indonesia, whose negotiation process began this year, as well as to resolve the Greater Sunrise issue, with the agreement expected to be signed at the beginning of next year. "He wants to resolve all these issues before leaving power. He does not want to leave these very complex dossiers to the new generation", added the President. Ideas and defenses José Ramos-Horta stated that he was not in favor of the unilateral declaration of independence, on November 28, 1975, considering that it was made “hastily” given the imminent occupation by Indonesia. "I was not in favor of the unilateral declaration of independence, I was, but it wasn't on November 28th. More preparation time was needed, because when you make a unilateral declaration of independence without any preparations, the result was what it was. There was no one. No one reacted", said Ramos-Horta, in an interview with Lusa on the occasion of the 50th anniversary. On November 28, 1975, the current head of state recalls a ceremony without the presence of a “single global personality” and a dark night. "The unilateral declaration of independence was made hastily for reasons determined by the circumstances of the time. The fall of Atabae [municipio de Bobonaro]", said Ramos-Horta. "The base fell with a large onslaught of regular Indonesian forces, already deep inside Timor-Leste. First Batugadé fell, that was in October, Balibó and Maliana fell, in October and Atabai, fell in the twenties of November. Soon after, Fretilin declared unilateral independence", explained the President. The occupation by Indonesia took place on December 7, 1975. “Indonesian forces were already in the national territory before December 7 and the decision in Jakarta had been made in 1974 either Timor-Leste integrates into Indonesia peacefully through some pseudo-democratic act, or Timor-Leste would pass to Indonesian domination by force”, said the Timorese head of state. The invasion is supported by the United States, Australia and some countries in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). "Obviously, in that context of 1975, the United States would not support Portugal on the issue of Timor-Leste. On the issue of Timor-Leste, Indonesia weighed more, especially in the post-Vietnam war context, in which the United States was discredited and fled. For the United States and for the countries in the region, the communist threat was real and Timor-Leste was isolated, abandoned", highlighted the Nobel Peace Prize winner. The liberation of Timor-Leste took place on August 30, 1999, when the referendum for self-determination took place, which gave victory to independence, which would eventually take place on May 20, 2002, after a transitional administration by the United Nations. “Twenty-four years later the country is freed against all the prophets of defeat, all those who preached realism to us, to me, some said atrocious unrealism, others said a lost cause, we heard a lot, including in Portugal”, added Ramos-Horta, highlighting that Timor-Leste managed to prevail. Defense of the constitutional amendment José Ramos-Horta defended, in the same interview, a constitutional amendment to adopt the presidential system in the country, because there is a need for “clear authority” and “without duality” and ruled out a re-candidacy for the position. "I believe that we should make a constitutional amendment and move to the presidential system. The President is the executive, the so-called semi-presidentialism is over", said José Ramos-Horta, in an interview with Lusa as part of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence, on November 28, 1975. Currently, Timor-Leste has a semi-presidential system with a parliamentary bias, with the Government emanating from parliament. According to the head of state, the system chosen in the Constitution, drawn up in 2001 and 2002, “has not been bad at all”, but it has been seen that instead of “instead of being a balancing factor”, it can be a “factor of instability”. Ramos-Horta exemplified what happened in the eighth Government, after the coalition led by Xanana Gusmão won the legislative elections with an absolute majority. “Xanana is invited to form a Government, they presented the list of rulers and President Lu Olo decides to veto, he did not want to inaugurate nine members”, said the Nobel Peace Prize winner. "It is necessary to have a clear authority and without this duality, to share power with the President. It doesn't work. It works well in Portugal", highlighted Ramos-Horta. For the Timorese President, “there is no reason” for Timor-Leste to have adopted that model, because “balance is the parliament, the judiciary”. "These three bodies are the constitution of the State. I think everyone will agree", he said. José Ramos-Horta considered that “it is time”, after around 25 years of the current Constitution, to make “some amendments” and move to the presidential system. "For me, Xanana Gusmão should continue. We reach 2027, my term ends, new elections in 2028. Between the period of 2027, in which I leave, and 2028, we actively work on a constitutional amendment so that the 2028 election is already based on the new Constitution, that is what I defend", he explained. When asked by Lusa whether he did not intend to run for a new term, the President stated that he was not “at least motivated”. “I, in 2027, will go to the transition ceremony of the portfolio for the new President at midnight on May 19, 2027 and I won't even attend the ceremony on the 20th. I'm already in AeroDili on my way to Singapore”, he stated. Problems of the new generation In the same conversation, José Ramos-Horta also highlighted some of the country's current problems, namely the fact that the generation after 1975 has not yet found a leader with national affirmation. He highlighted that since 2002, members of this generation have held seats in the Government and parliament. "The new generation has been there since 2002. The problem is that the new generation has not yet found a single person to assert themselves as a national leader. They have not yet appeared. That is the problem. They are in the Government, in the courts, in parliament, all new generations", said the President in an interview with Lusa on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence. José Ramos-Horta also questioned who is the leader of the new generation that “has a national dimension”. “There is none, not one, because in a democracy you have to win the electorate”, he said, highlighting that a party is created and that party competes in the elections. The head of state highlighted, however, that today Timor-Leste already has 210 doctorates and 1,700 masters, graduated from “good universities” and “there are people who know”. Timorese civil society has accused the current Timorese leadership, which continues to focus on figures from the resistance era, of creating obstacles to the emergence of new leaders with the capacity to respond to contemporary challenges. Asked whether, after 50 years of the unilateral declaration of independence, the Timorese are reconciled, Ramos-Horta stated that among the “factions of [19]75 more than reconciled”. "Some have even died, the majority have died. There is no problem at all. When I see some brilliant being saying 'they are still the divisions of 75', you don't know that the majority have already died, only if they are the souls in the cemetery", said José Ramos-Horta. According to the President, the divisions result from the democratic struggle. “I find it ridiculous, interesting, sometimes frustrating when I hear that the Timorese are divided,” said the President. "Very well, let's all unite like it is done in North Korea, or rather, single party, single candidate, it is already known who wins the elections in North Korea, so there is not much headache, everything is simple, 97% votes for Kim Jong-un, then they do the recount and after all it was not 97%, but it was 101%. It's an option, then we are all united", joked Ramos-Horta. But, he added, the Timorese chose democracy. "A democracy that is praised today and survives the wave of setbacks against democracy in Asia, Latin America, Africa and Europe. We are doing very well with democracy", he concluded.

item.title: Cuca Roseta, fado singer: “Fado is samba-poetry sung from the heart”
item.description:
During the pandemic, she sang for the Macau public through a video concert, but now, the fado singer gives her heart and soul to a concert with the Macau Chinese Orchestra, part of the lineup for the Macau International Music Festival, next Saturday, 11th. In an interview with HM, Cuca Roseta talks about the show's lineup, her 15-year career and the truth found in her compositions. Performs in Macau on October 11th with the Macau Chinese Orchestra (OCM). Tell me a little about what we can expect from this show. Yes, we are finally going to Macau. It will be the first time because we previously did a video concert for Macau during the pandemic, and we were unable to be there physically. We now work with OCM, which is very good, and I am happy with this partnership, for being able to unite, in some way, two cultures. We are a little anxious about that fact. The concert will have songs such as “Meu”, “Preto e Branco”, “Canção do Mar”, “Não Sei de Onde” and “Finalmente”. What does this alignment bring us? We already had arrangements made for orchestra by Marinho de Freitas, which are extraordinary arrangements, and which will be adapted to the traditional OCM instruments. These songs are practically all written by me, lyrics and music, and tell different stories, some that I have lived myself or stories that, in some way, I have experienced someone living very closely. They are original fados. “Canção do Mar” is very old and became known in the voices of Dulce Pontes and Amália Rodrigues, and has a new arrangement. We thought it would look beautiful with OCM. Of course, there are songs that we always sing and that never leave the repertoire, linked to traditional phases of my career. There are some songs that people like and request, but we bring a completely different repertoire to what we presented at the time [in Macau, with the video concert], which was very well received. It was a concert that went very well, even though it was via video, and we received wonderful messages. This year he released the album “Até a Fé Se Esqueceu”, which has an exclusively Brazilian repertoire, with several names in Brazilian music, such as Seu Jorge or Zeca Pagodinho. Why explore this universe, mixing it with the language of Fado? Yes, but this year I will also release a French album with Amália Rodrigues' agent, who invited me. But “Até a Fé Se Esqueceu” came from an invitation from a great Brazilian producer to record old sambas, which have a lot to do with Fado. Even though it's a Brazilian album, all sambas, it's my saddest album of all, the most melancholic. That's why we went looking for this root of samba to find great poets and great composers that Brazil has, and who have this weight that Fado also has. As? Fado has a lot to do with words and composition, in fact, Fado is samba-poetry sung from the heart, because there has to be this truth in the interpretation, the idea of ​​truth coming from life's experiences, in transforming the story it tells. This melancholy is in the veins of Portuguese blood and is mixed with art and music. This invitation wanted to put a fado singer to sing seriously and with the weight that Fado brings, and be able to interpret the great poets and sambas. The album [Até a Fé Se Esqueceu] has very old sambas, one of them from 1937. It is, therefore, a very strong and even very beautiful album, with great poems and composers, such as Tom Jobim, Vinicius de Morais, and wonderful partnerships with Seu Jorge and Zeca Pagodinho, who came to Fado. It's an album that made me really proud.
Therefore, it is possible to marry Fado with the joy of samba, which also has a melancholic side, right? Like the melancholy of our Fado. In fact, when we hear the word samba we think of joy, but in fact the basis of samba is not joy. There is that phrase by Vinicius de Morais, “To make a samba beautifully you need a bit of sadness, otherwise you won’t make a samba”. So that's where the beauty of this work lies, which goes to the roots of samba and shows that there aren't that many differences between the melancholy at the root of samba and the melancholy of Fado. It's a nostalgic and melancholic album, it doesn't bring that joy. It can bring hope, and we can say that some themes bring with them this hope, which we find in Brazilian culture and drums. Because they literally put their sadness on the skirt wheel and on the drums, right? They transform sadness into dance and music, but in this work we don't see that type of samba. Cuca also has a previous album, “Cabo Verde Nha Cretcheu”, so it can be said that she has explored, in her career, the different Portuguese-speaking sounds, going beyond Fado, mixing sounds? This album didn't come from my will, and I think [it's a sign] that life takes me, deep down. This album was born from a tour I took across the nine islands of Cape Verde with a live recording of the mornas I sang on each island, as I sang the traditional mornas of each island. Between one island and another there are very different moraines. What I did was, after my Fado concerts, I sang two mornas and then we compiled all the songs in Creole in celebration of the fact that I was the first international artist to do the nine islands in a row. But I was also in Goa and did my concert in Concanim. I find it easy and enjoy learning the traditional songs of the countries where I am going to sing. I already sang in Moscow and learned a Russian song; I learned the songs of Goa, and in Georgia, in Tblisi, I also learned a song. It's a treat I make when I travel around the world taking Fado. But morna is wonderful and there really are similarities between this musical genre, and I wanted to bring this encounter between Fado and morna to Cape Verdeans, and this album came about, which is beautiful. Once it goes to Macau, can we expect a song in Cantonese, or Mandarin? Yes. By chance, I had already spoken to my manager to contact someone in this regard, so that we could discover a traditional song that I could learn. Last year, he celebrated 15 years of career. How do you review your career, which began with the albums “Cuca Roseta” and “Raiz”? In fact, it was great to celebrate 15 years at MEO Arena [the concert hall in Lisbon], and be able to revisit all the albums since the first. “Raiz” opened something that is rarer, which is the fado singer composing and writing her lyrics. This was a record that went wonderfully well and, from then on, it was good, because in this search for the truth that Fado has, being able to compose and write your own lyrics always means giving a little more of yourself. Each person composes and writes in their own way, and when they can do it, it is always a bit like the lines on the palm of their hand, that is, it is something unique. In this search that people make to follow standards to achieve success, I believe that success exists when we are not afraid to follow our voice and our instinct, what comes from our heart, tell our stories and sing our melodies without fear. In this way we end up becoming unique. Although it is not usual in Fado for a fado singer to compose and write, it was nice to see that my songs became important to many fans. Sometimes I have great composers and poets [to collaborate with me], but I think [writing and composing] brings out this side of the person being more truthful. My poems can never be compared to those of the great poets I have sung, but I think people feel that I am more in my own skin. In a way, this touches and moves them. Celebrating 15 years of career was the closing of a cycle and the beginning of another, and it was great to return to the “roots”, and realize that that was where the “gunpowder” lay, in the sense of not being afraid of ourselves.

item.title: Piménio Ferreira: “Anti-gypsy rhetoric has always worked in Portugal”
item.description: Piménio Ferreira, better known as Gitelles Ferreira, anti-racist activist, 34 years old, physical engineer, Romani national. He is a man with a provocative speech, a corrosive, gentle humor and a smile that leaves no one indifferent. Gitelles, we live in an intercultural land and gypsies – in particular – have lived in Portugal for around five centuries. What happens so that gypsy communities continue to be “on the margins” of so-called society? We need to change the model of society. This is extremely stratified, placing people in subordinate positions to privilege a violent minority. The white social structure is patriarchal and racist. What is called the ‘margin’ of society is in fact an intrinsic place within it, which belongs to it. In other words, gypsy people have been included in this model of society since they discovered Europe and its kingdoms. The problem is the model of society that is maintained and the place to which they were relegated and how they were relegated: with violence, in a status of inferiority compared to white people, without the right to human dignity, to found a family, to choose their own language and religion, expropriated of any and all cultural and material rights. A place built and maintained to this day by genocidal and ethnocidal violence and persecution. In 1463, Vasco Gitano was granted an estate. In 1521, the gitanos, or gypsies, were already used as a reference for everything that is considered bad in the model of society. The “counter-example” compared to white that would stand out in a positive way. The ‘angel’ and the ‘demon’; the ‘other’, the enemy; the one against whom any attack and persecution is legitimate. Including the prohibition of defending oneself, having weapons, any type of property, and the right to stay.
